description: “Trap” marks as Lenny’s first song of 2019, and the third single off of his second studio album “Ghetto Lenny’s Love Songs”. Noteworthy is this also only the second song ever from Lenny, with a feature on it, with the first one being “Lust” featuring Janelle Kroll.  “Trap” is Lenny and Lil Baby showing how they’re both dealing with their newfound fame and wealth after being raised in a tough environment. The pair share a lot of similarities, with them both being raised by a single mother in poverty, then turning to drug dealing at a young age to earn money. Lenny has been verbal on many occasions, that if it wouldn’t have been for rap, he would most likely still be selling drugs, which he even has a song about, titled “Dope Dealer” released through his rap-collective GØDD COMPLEXx. Same goes for Baby, who never thought that rap was going to be his career. But after being pursued by Quality Control Music’s Pee and Coach K to keep on rapping, kept him out of the drug selling business

description: “Monica Lewinsky” is a reference to Monica Lewinsky, the famous secretary who had an affair with Bill Clinton.  This track marks the first collaboration between the two main artists.  This track also seems to interpolate the instrumentation of dvsn’s “Hallucinations” though this in not confirmed.

description: “Reflex” is the second single heating up listeners for the release of his debut album, coming few months after well-received “Roses”. The track was released on 23rd September of 2016, way before the official release of said Collection One, which happened to date on the 30th March 2018 – nearly 2 years after.  Sonically, the song was handled by SAINt JHN’s go-to producer –  F a l l e n , who set up some cloud mood mixed with hard-hitting trap banger.

description: “Sucks To Be You” is the first track from SAINt JHN’s 2020 album: “While The World Was Burning”. The song documents a period in SAINt JHN’s life where he had experienced homelessness due to his Mother kicking him out of the house.  His friend, Kyra, gave him a place to stay for three years as he pursued his aspirations.  The song was released as a single prior to the albums release on October 26th 2020.

description: On November 19, 2017, Trippie Redd teased this song on Instagram Live, saying: “Can you guess who’s featured on this? He loves cactuses”, before singing the hook of Travis Scott’s “90210.” The following day, Travis tweeted the lyrics of this song’s hook, essentially confirming that he was featured on the track. Over the following days, Trippie continuously teased the song on Instagram, saying that he was waiting for Travis to send back his verse.  On November 29, Trippie uploaded another video to Instagram, teasing Travis' part to the song. Trippie originally hinted on the post that he would release the song after the post receives 100,000 comments saying “1400/800”, however, it was deleted later that night. Not long before it was deleted, Travis Tweeted about leaks with several angry emojis, leading some to believe that was the reason why Trippie deleted the video.  The song was released on December 5, 2017, and marks the first collaboration between the two artists.  The title seems to be a reference to the groundbreaking 2008 Christoper Nolan Batman film, “The Dark Knight.” It also seems to make reference to 6ix9ine’s “Gummo,” which is where the ‘Dummo’ from the title comes from. They were recently engaged in beef after they had a fight backstage at ‘Day ‘N Night’ festival.  It’s also worth noting that the melody that Trippie uses in the hook is very reminiscent of the melody he used on XXXTENTACION’s “Fuck Love.”

description: “I Kill People” is Trippie Redd’s second single of 2018, following “UKA UKA.” The song appears to be a ‘diss’ aimed at fellow rapper and rival 6ix9ine.  A snippet first appeared on Trippie Redd’s Instagram page on 8 May, 2018. A few days prior to this, fellow rapper and GloGang/GBE member Tadoe appeared in a video on 6ix9ine’s Instagram bragging about “killing people” because of 6ix9ine’s involvement with Tadoe’s ex-girlfriend, Cuban Doll. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pOz2HpZctrA  Each artist on this track, at the time of its release, had issues with 6ix9ine. Trippie Redd and 6ix9ine have had ongoing issues since 6ix9ine’s legal issues came to light in 2017. In May of 2018, 6ix9ine started beef with Chief Keef with a disrespectful instagram video.

description: After several teasers Trippie Redd finally debuted the track, Topanga. The track features an upbeat, gospel instrumental produced by Chopsquad DJ. Throughout the track Trippie melodically sings about gun possession and gun violence, along with references to religion and the California city, Topanga.

description: “1400 / 999 Freestyle” is a long-awaited collaboration with melancholic rapper, Juice WRLD. Both 1400 and 999 are used on the song title as these numbers represent both Trippie and Juice, respectively.  Trippie released a short snippet of this song on his story on October 10, 2018. In September 2018, The NoJumper YouTube channel also included a short snippet, in addition to the making of the song in a vlog, as both Juice and Trippie are shown listening to the song.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KkU31Ifv1x4

description: Trippie Redd takes a juxtapositional approach on “Taking A Walk”, the title coupled with the airy instrumental creates a light-hearted and happy ambiance. Despite this, Trippie is actually referencing death, which contrasts the happy sounding beat.  While he initially posted a snippet of this song in December of 2017, it was deleted and re-uploaded in early March 2018.  On April 4, 2018, Trippie posted a second snippet on his Instagram story. Here, he appeared in the studio with Nebu Kiniza, thus raising speculation over a potential feature. Despite this, there was no feature on the finished song.  Trippie released the song on August 6, 2018, as part of the pre-release for his first studio album, LIFE’S A TRIP, which was later released on August 10 of the same year.

description: Lil Nas X enlists established country singer Billy Ray Cyrus for a surprise remix of his smash breakout hit, “Old Town Road.” Cyrus previously co-signed the original song via Twitter, saying:  Been watching everything going on with OTR. When I got thrown off the charts, Waylon Jennings said to me ‘Take this as a compliment’ means you’re doing something great! Only Outlaws are outlawed. Welcome to the club!  Cyrus' feature comes in spite of the removal of the song from the Billboard Country charts, which sparked debate as to whether the original song qualified as a country song or was more closely aligned with hip-hop.  https://pbs.twimg.com/media/D3WuqdRV4AEj-RO?format=jpg&name=4096x4096  Lil Nas X with Billy Ray Cyrus during the studio session for "Old Town Road (Remix)"

description: On “Old Town Road,” Lil Nas X romanticizes the life of a cowboy. The character is unfulfilled by a hedonistic life of consumerism, substance abuse, and adultery. He also has dissatisfaction with the indolence of his peers, feeling no need to heed their advice. With nothing left to believe in or follow, the rider heads out with the only destination being the open road.  “Old Town Road” grew in popularity through numerous TikTok memes. Similarly to how the Atlanta duo iLOVEFRiDAY’s hit song “Mia Khalifa” blew up, clips on TikTok with the hashtag #oldtownroad have garnered millions of views.  After the song was removed from Billboard’s Country charts for “not (embracing) enough elements of today’s country music to chart in its current version,” Lil Nas X released a remix of his song with Billy Ray Cyrus to spite the company. The original eventually reached the number 1 spot on the Billboard Hot 100 on April 8, 2019.  Both the original version and the remix credits Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross of Nine Inch Nails for sampling their track, “34 Ghosts IV.”

description: On “MONTERO (Call Me By Your Name),” Lil Nas X wants to stop pretending with his significant other and act on a first-name basis. The song’s title references Lil Nas X’s real name, Montero Lamar Hill.  The track first surfaced as a snippet on Twitter in July 9th, 2020. In November of the same year, Nas X stated that “Call Me By Your Name” would be the next song he releases, announced via Instagram Live.  On February 2nd, 2021, a Super Bowl ad for Logitech starring Nas X was released, using the song. It was revealed in the ad’s description that the song was called “Montero (Call Me By Your Name).”  Lil Nas X later partnered with MSCHF, a company that makes viral products, to make a special edition of Nike Air Max 97s, known as the “Satan Shoes.” The shoes sold out in under a minute and the final pair, #666, is being given out via a Twitter lottery. They were priced at $1,018, a reference to the Bible passage Luke 10:18, which reads: “I saw Satan fall like lightning from heaven.”    The release of the shoes, as well as the music video for the track, which sees Nas sliding down a pole into Hell and grinding on the Devil, garnered controversy among religious and conservative groups. However, the backlash only helped the song’s popularity.

description: “Panini” is the second single from Lil Nas X’s debut EP, 7, following his hit song, “Old Town Road.” It was first previewed on his Instagram on April 2nd, 2019, with the caption, “Sayyyyyy tooo meee.”  In this song, Lil Nas talks about his old fanbase and compares them to Panini, a character from the popular TV Series Chowder.  Nas explained what he meant by the song in a Genius suggestion:  Panini was possessive over Chowder in the show. She’s a representation of fans of who love you when you’re small. Once you get the spotlight they aren’t feeling you as much. The song is not a diss but anger towards that fan but also wanting them back.  On May 12, 2019, Lil Nas premiered the song in its entirety for the first time at the Rolling Loud music festival.

description: “HOLIDAY” is the first single from Lil Nas X’s upcoming debut studio album and his first official release since the January 2020 remix of “Rodeo,” featuring hip-hop legend Nas.  Nas first teased incoming new music on November 4, 2020, with an Instagram post captioned “❄️💜nasvember.” A snippet of the track and its Christmas-themed accompanying music video was then teased in a commercial during the Tampa Bay Buccaneers v. New Orleans Saints Sunday Night Football game on November 8, 2020.

description: “C7osure (You Like)” finds Nas telling someone he loves (maybe, his fans or his family) that he needs to grow, and that fear or worry won’t hold him back: a similar theme is present on “Panini,” a more direct “letter” to those who have been disappointed by his rapid rise to fame.  The song was first teased on June 7, 2019, just two weeks before the release of the artist’s debut project.  On June 30, 2019, the last day of Pride Month, Hill went to Twitter in order to reveal the true personal meaning of the song, as he came out to the world by being his most authentic self in terms of his sexuality (as he seemingly declared himself to be a member of the LGBTQ+ community) and his music.

description: Lil Nas X and Billy Ray Cyrus enlist the help of fellow Atlanta rapper, Young Thug, and Mason Ramsey for the third remix of his hit song, “Old Town Road.” The first remix featured country legend Billy Ray Cyrus while the second remix was with American DJ, Diplo.  Lil Nas X previously talked about Thug’s role in the country trap genre in an interview with XXL, saying:  But with country trap, I in no way want to take credit for that. I believe Young Thug would be one of the biggest pioneers in that.  The remix was previewed by both Lil Nas X and Thug via Instagram on April 9, 2019. It marks the first time that Lil Nas X, Thug, and Ramsey have collaborated with any of each other.

description: In the lead single for his mixtape Code Red, Moneybagg Yo dismisses his haters who have lots to say, but can’t back up their words. What matters to him is that he’s rich and they’re broke.  The song was first previewed on Bagg’s Instagram on June 29, 2020, the day before its release.

description: “U Played” is a club banger by rappers Moneybagg Yo and Lil Baby. The Tay Keith-produced track served as the second single to Bagg’s third studio album Time Served.  Bagg first previewed the song in a now-deleted Twitter post on January 2, 2020. He released the music video ten days following the track’s release.

description: “Self Care” is Mac spreading a message about overcoming hardships, self control, and being aware of how to handle yourself.  When tweeting about their relationship, Ariana states that Mac’s “inability to keep his shit together” was a significant reason why the relationship broke down and “Self Care” could also be Mac’s way of trying to learn from that mistake.  In the music video that was released along with the single, Mac is buried in a pine box to symbolize how the media tried to assassinate his character. In the casket, Mac lights a cigarette despite having no source of oxygen, displaying that he is confident that he will overcome his obstacles and make it out. With his knife, he carves “memento mori” into the lid which translates to “remember that you have to die” and he punches through it to save himself, a symbol showing that he refuses to die any time soon.

description: “Good News” is Mac Miller’s first officially released music since his death in September of 2018. It is also the first single from Miller’s sixth studio album and first posthumous project, Circles. The track first appeared online on September 1, 2019. At the time, it was rumored to be part of an unreleased project that Miller was working on around the time of the release of his fifth studio album Swimming in August 2018. It was later released, along with an accompanying music video, and finally confirmed to be on his posthumous album, Circles, on January 9, 2020.  On the track, Miller discusses many of the same themes seen on his last record, Swimming. He speaks on feeling no reprieve from negative feelings in life, while the people around him only want him to say that he’s good, wanting him to suppress the negative feelings he has all the time.  The track’s music video features clips of Miller recording music, as well as many animated nature scapes depicting the positive parts of the world that Miller wants to find on the track.

description: “2009” is a reflective journey from the year before Mac’s breakout mixtape, K.I.D.S, was released to the present day. He speaks to the listener about the lessons he’s learned and the wisdom he’s gained throughout the track.

description: Despite the extended love imagery, this song is NOT about a girl:  https://twitter.com/MacMiller/status/339882246934777856  Mac tells us the truth in his Billboard Track by Track interview that this song uses the imagery of a female to personify all his addictions, such as drugs and music.

description: “Cinderella”, featuring Ty Dolla $ign, is track five of The Divine Feminine, the fourth studio album by Mac Miller. This is the first time the two artists have collaborated. Miller portrays vivid feelings for a lover in this song. The beat samples the Tokyo Police Club song “Tessellate”.  After Mac Miller and Ariana Grande broke up, many people had begun to blame her for leaving him after “allegedly” recording an album about her. Through a Twitter reply, Grande stated that “Cinderella” is the only song that is actually dedicated towards her.

description: On “Come Back To Earth” Mac provides a cathartic, gentle foundation to begin Swimming. The album’s recurring motifs of self care, self acceptance and personal liberation are introduced through the swimming metaphor.  Mac also establishes the conflict between a new found sense of optimism and his perennial challenges with depression, isolation and addiction.  Mac first teased the song in a tweet on July 12th, 2018, released alongside the video for “Self Care”. https://twitter.com/MacMiller/status/1017454034167316480

description: On “SAD!” X laments about the struggle of letting go of a loved one and the feeling of depression that follows.  He details emotions of uncertainty surrounding a specific relationship. He is insecure and heartbroken due to the fact that his girlfriend had left him, bringing about a melancholy vibe.  He also brings up suicide, a subject often discussed throughout his discography. For example, in the song “Jocelyn Flores” from his 2017 album, 17, he raps about a friend who suffered from depression and eventually killed herself.  This song was frequently teased as an intro of X’s gaming videos on his YouTube channel prior to its release.

description: Jocelyn Flores was a friend of X who suffered from depression and committed suicide in May 2017, while staying with him in Florida for a photoshoot. He posted tweets about the situation, but they were later deleted. In an Instagram Live video, X detailed the events personally,  It was a devastating situation to deal with, it fucked me up so bad to where I wasn’t on social media for the last few days unless I was addressing something that I needed to. I never thought I would feel something for someone I barely knew that would fuck me up so bad just because I came from it  He previously dedicated the song “Revenge” to Jocelyn shortly after she died – he didn’t discuss her death on the track, although he wrote it in the song’s description on SoundCloud, “Rest in peace, Jocelyn, I will have my revenge upon the world.”  This song was performed over “im closing my eyes,” a potsu-produced song that samples the lyrics from Shiloh Dynasty’s “I Knew You So Well.” Two other tracks on 17 were also produced by potsu: “Everybody Dies In Their Nightmares” and “Carry On.”  On August 5, 2017, X uploaded a snippet of the song on his Snapchat story.

description: “Look At Me” was first released on December 30, 2015, via Soundcloud. It samples “Changes” by Mala.  The track received a second surge in popularity in late January 2017, when Drake previewed a song eventually released as “KMT,” which had a similar sounding flow.  After hearing the preview for “KMT,” X tweeted his frustration at the similarities. Drake denied stealing the flow, though he admitted there were similarities, prompting X to respond from jail, saying he would rather a big name artist like Drake help with his legal situation, rather than steal his flow and not give any credit.  Subsequently, in May 2017, “Look At Me!” was edited for better sound quality and placed on his Revenge mixtape, giving it a wider release on streaming services.  The controversial music video for “Look At Me!” released on September 12, 2017.

description: “Fuck Love” is the 8th track of X’s debut album, 17, unveiled a day before release and is also the only track on the album to feature another artist. It features Canton, Ohio raised hip-hop artist, Trippie Redd, who has recently been gaining publicity from tracks like “Love Scars” and “Poles 1469.” This is the second song X and Trippie have collaborated together on; the first being a remix of Trippie’s song “Owee,”“ titled “Uh Oh, Thots!.”  X tweeted that “Fuck Love” will be the only song off 17 that’ll be posted on SoundCloud. It was removed after X’s Soundcloud was hacked but later re-uploaded.  This song holds the record for most streams of any song on the SoundCloud platform with over 250 million plays.

description: “Revenge” is a song that is dedicated to his late friend, Jocelyn Flores, who committed suicide in the bathroom of his hotel room while visiting him. This is the the only single released to promote his debut album, 17.  This song was first previewed on Twitter on May 9th and released officially on X’s SoundCloud titled as “garette’s REVENGE” on May 18th.  https://twitter.com/xxxtentacion/status/862166445844647936  X posted a Snapchat about the video saying,  For those of you that saw that video on my Twitter, I produced that..all of it..completely original.

description: “changes” is the 15th track off of XXXTENTACION’s album, ?. It was released on March 2nd, 2018, everywhere along with “SAD!.”  On March 1st, 2018, he announced on his Instagram story that he would be releasing two songs at midnight.  The bridge is sung by PnB Rock, a friend of X’s who has stated that the pair would collaborate on many occasions since X was released from jail in March 2017.  https://www.instagram.com/p/BkOpSkPHsjc/?taken-by=pnbrock

description: A snippet of this song was previewed on XXXTENTACION’s Instagram page and was given temporary titles such as “Planet Uranus” and “Spotlight”.  https://youtu.be/1G2ljBEuAu0?t=23s  “Moonlight” is a smooth love song about a girl who X seems to admire and gets jealous over, as well as a track that outlines his success despite dealing with mental health issues and his dark past.  The official video clip of the song was released after his death on September 30, 2018 on X’s YouTube channel.

description: Only seven months after likening himself to a “POP STAR,” DaBaby teams up with fellow 2019 superstar Roddy Ricch for “ROCKSTAR,” an ode to their reckless lifestyles.  DaBaby and Roddy draw hip-hop’s popular parallel between their life and that of rockstars, substituting a rocker’s typical guitar for a firearm. Additionally, the duo compares their rise to the top and express their loyalty to family and loved ones.  The song’s upbeat, guitar-driven trap instrumental is produced by DaBaby’s frequent collaborator, SethInTheKitchen, who notably produced Baby’s 2019 track, “iPHONE.”

description: In the second track from his Baby on Baby album, Charlotte rapper DaBaby delivers a homage to Marion “Suge” Knight, the founder, and former head of Death Row Records.  Knight became the CEO of Death Row in 1991 when he was just 26 years old, which was just a year younger than DaBaby’s age at the time of this tracks release.  In the song, the rapper discusses several topics, including his riches, selling drugs, signing record deals, and threatening opposition.  “Suge” was officially released to radio as a single on April 23, 2019 and was certified Gold on May 15.

description: Similar to “Suge” from DaBaby’s debut album Baby On Baby, the success of “BOP” was already present upon release and was skyrocketed with the release of the music video. On November 15, 2019, DaBaby released “BOP on Broadway” aka the hip-hop musical which was shot, directed, and edited by the Reel Goats. Appearances from the Jabbawockeez as well as choreography from DaniLeigh played a part in the video being as viral as it was.

description: On the opening track to his sophomore album KIRK, North Carolina rapper DaBaby reminisces about his past and reflects on his rise to mainstream fame. In particular, DaBaby juxtaposes his poor upbringing with the newfound success he experiences, while also looking back on how he changed along the way.  This song was released in dedication of his deceased father and his grandmother, who untimely passed away during his come-up in the rap game. The “INTRO” is an unusual track from DaBaby, as it features hard-hitting lyricism and introspective bars, straying from his typical subject matter.  This track serves as the first promotional single for KIRK, which is unorthodox since rappers typically don’t release introduction tracks on albums as solo songs.

description: “Goin Baby” is a boastful track from North Carolina rapper DaBaby who brags about his sexual prowess and privileged lifestyle.  The music video for the track was released on March 25, 2019. It features him flying in a plane and parading in the streets of New York City.

description: “VIBEZ” features the Charlotte rapper speaking on the “vibes” that he and his crew bring to anywhere they are, as well as the money and women involved with those vibes.  The track was first previewed by DaBaby on September 24, in a Trilller video that he posted to his Instagram account. The song was identified to be “VIBEZ” by the music-identifying app Shazam.  A music video for the track was released on October 1, 2019.

description: DaBaby flexes his lyrical abilities and flows on “Next Song,” which serves as the intro on DaBaby’s 2018 mixtape Blank Blank and is one of his most famous songs to date. On the track, he raps about his competition in the rap game and details his privileged lifestyles.  He released the music video on Youtube, on November 2nd, 2018.

description: Serving as the emerging Memphis rapper’s official solo debut, “Shotta Flow” emphasizes NLE Choppa’s energetic delivery and infectious flow. While the lines themselves can be equated to relatively generic braggadocio, they have that punchy, Memphis bounce that keeps true throughout the flow switch-ups.  “Shotta Flow” marks the second collaboration between Choppa and producer Midas800, the first being “Hit the Scene.” Midas can be recognized by his signature tag, referencing Greek mythological figure King Midas.

description: “Shotta Flow (Remix)” is a remix of NLE Choppa’s breakout hit “Shotta Flow”, with an assisted feature from rapper Blueface, marking the first collaborative effort between the two artists.  “Shotta Flow (Remix)” was originally teased on Blueface’s Instagram story on April 17th, 2019, and was previewed in a 35-second snippet. The snippet only featured parts of Blueface’s verse and did not feature any of Choppa’s verse.  The highly anticipated remix dropped June 20, 2019, with an accompanying music video that was uploaded to the Lyrical Lemonade YouTube Channel.

description: On “Camelot,“ NLE Choppa reiterates the successful formula used on his breakout song, “Shotta Flow,” by energetically delivering hot bars about threatening his opposition and detailing his dangerous lifestyle.  The song was released as a single and quickly gained popularity, supported by the accompanying Lyrical Lemonade music video, which racked up more than 5 million views in only one day.  For further information about the song, check out the Genius video that dives into the meaning of “Camelot”: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ypumHswGNok

description: “Shotta Flow 3” is NLE Choppa’s third rendition of his breakout hit “Shotta Flow” which released in January of 2019. “Shotta Flow 3” was first previewed on Choppa’s Instagram on July 7, 2019, in a one-minute snippet. The snippet contained, Choppa freestyling to the beat as he did for “Shotta Flow”.

description: “Shotta Flow 2” is NLE Choppa’s second rendition  of his breakout hit, “Shotta Flow.” NLE continues with his energetic & vigorous flow throughout the track, which is not too different from his original hit.  A snippet of the song was published onto YouTube on January 26th, 2019.

description: “Walk Em Down” is the first collaboration between NLE Choppa and Roddy Ricch. On October 2, 2019, NLE Choppa shared a video of him dancing and previewed a snippet of the track via his Instagram story.

description: When NLE made this song, He was at One Sound Studio in Memphis, South Memphis. He recorded “Shotta Flow” there, “Shotta Flow 2” there. That was where he recorded my first song at, actually. The first song he ever recorded. One Sound’s home, pretty much. Minus, he sent the beat to NLE’s phone. He did the “Shotta Flow” beat. He worked with him in the past. NLE was like, “Bruh, this beat a song,”. He was tryin to dissect it. He was like, “What i'mma do wit it?” And he had to just listen ‘til I really found out what he wanted to do with the beat. He usually freestyle on my songs. But he wrote most of this song. NLE wrote the hook. The hook especially ‘cause he knew that was the grabber of the song. That was the part NLE really, know what I’m sayin’, put my most focus on. When NLE said, “Before you try rob, hit your knees and pray to Buddha,” from that point on it was a freestyle. That was a freestyle from that point on. He usually, if I write, I don’t ever write two verses cause he don’t really have that much time. He write one verse and then he say, “Imma just freestyle the other verse.” When he made the song and it was done NLE was like, “Yeah, it’s hit, for sho.” He thinks with “Capo” NLE made it a bit more melodic and stuff just because he wanted to do somethin’ different. NLE tryin' to stay different. It’s just somethin' clicked in his head like, “Bruh, do this. This shit is gon' be hard.” And he changed it up, and when NLE made this song he was like, “Bruh, this, know what I’m sayin, it’s a slap on God.”

description: On “Love Me,” Weezy, Drake, and Future talk about their women and how they care about nothing but them—as long as they love them back. It was released as the second single from Wayne’s tenth studio album, I Am Not a Human Being II.  The song was a success, peaking at #9 on the Billboard Hot 100—notably becoming Future’s first and only top ten single until he released “Mask Off” in February 2017, which peaked at #5.  The official music video premiered on February 14, 2013, on MTV Jams. In an interview with MTV News a day prior, Wayne talked about the concept of the music video:  The concept of the video is really just to create awesome scenery. A scenery that every man… anyone wanna be in […] I appreciate Drake and Future for doin’ this because I’m quite sure they’re hella busy like I am, but I ain’t never too busy to get in a bed with three women, with water everywhere.

description: Floyd Mayweather Instagrammed footage of the studio session when Wayne and Drake were recording this.  Drake addresses his mentor and career succession. Mostly he talks about the fact that rappers don’t know his potential yet and are pushing him over the edge.  Wayne performed the track the night after its release at the Floyd Mayweather fight.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uiIrN24c2Xg  Drake previewed a snippet of the track at a club, prior to the song’s official release.

description: “Mona Lisa” is a story of a deceptive woman named Liz who sets her “boyfriend” up for a robbery.  Liz is compared to the famous portrait painting due to the dubiety of Mona Lisa’s smile. The smile can be interpreted as disingenuous, which therefore makes Liz disingenuous as well, unbeknownst to the boyfriend. Wayne and Kendrick play the two sides of the story; Wayne is the robber and Kendrick is the boyfriend.  The song was originally recorded in 2014, as it appeared on the tentative Carter V tracklist that Wayne previewed in October 2014. The first snippet of the song was brought to light in 2017 when PharmaBro Martin Shkreli played a part of the song live on Periscope, after acquiring the album from a man who bought Lil Wayne’s Bugatti, where a copy of the album was left. The version that Shkreli played live was later leaked in September 2019, along with the rest of the original Carter V album.   The song also notably contains references to Wayne’s relationship with Karrine Steffans, who is also known as Superhead. In an interview with BET Digital shortly after the song’s release, Steffans confirmed this, noting the song’s lyrics bared “similarities” to her relationship with Wayne.

description: The first single off Carter IV features rap aristocrat Cory Gunz & Lil Wayne yearning to go home (Harry Belafonte style..)  In the House of Detention for Men, the oldest jail on Rikers Island, each inmate’s cell is 6 feet by 8 feet by 7 feet.  Wayne flexes on a rather minimalistic beat.

description: With a sung portion by Bruno Mars, himself a subject of some strong opinions, this song examines Weezy’s past relationship with drugs and where it could lead him in the future.  Notably, the entire track sees Wayne talking to his reflection in a mirror, self-reflecting in an attempt to truly “see Wayne”.

description: “Rich As Fuck” is a braggadocious anthem on which Lil Wayne and 2 Chainz flex their personal and crew’s wealth.  “Rich As Fuck” was the third and final single off Wayne’s tenth studio album I AM NOT A HUMAN BEING II. It peaked at #38 on the Billboard 100 chart and was later certified platinum by RIIA.  On the “leak version,” the two verses are inverted, contrary to the iTunes Version.  The music video premiered on March 22, 2013 via MTV.

description: Co-written by Lee Brice, Rob Hatch, and Dallas Davidson, and released on February 18, 2014 as the first single and title track from Brice’s third studio album, which debuted on September 9, 2014.  According to tasteofcountry.com, Brice wrote the lyrics to his wife Sara, and “penned this song for their wedding dance.”

description: “I Drive Your Truck” is a song inspired by the true story of an American soldier named Jared Monti. While the song orients itself to being about a brother who was lost in Afghanistan, it was inspired by a father’s story about his son. Jared Monti was ultimately killed in the line of duty while trying multiple times to save a fellow soldier who was gravely wounded.  The inspiration came when co-writer Connie Harrington heard an interview with Jared Monti’s father, Paul Monti, on NPR’s show Here and Now, where Paul explained one of the ways he reconnects with his son’s memory, by driving his son’s truck.  The song is emotional and deep, and tells the listener of how the protagonist drives their bother’s truck to keep their memory alive, and portrays the pain they feel over the loss.

description: “Love Like Crazy” was country star Lee Brice’s fourth single. The song is an ode to a old fashioned man who lived a life of passion and taking big risks. It focuses on the long and happy marriage he had with his high school sweetheart, and the magnificent career he built starting from the bottom. In addition to being the type of “story song” that country music is so famous for, it’s also a song where the protagonist gives the listener good lessons on how to live your life like he did, by namely loving like crazy.  The song set some interesting records in country music.  By September 2010, it had remained on  the Billboard Hot Country chart the longest of any song in history. It also entered the chart’s top 10 in its 46th week on the chart, making it the song to climb into the top 10 the slowest. It ultimately went on to be a huge hit for Brice as it became a #1 song and was certified Platinum by the RIAA (1,000,000+ copies sold).  One of the songwriters, and the track’s producer, Doug Johnson gave an interview to theboot.com where he discusses the inspiration and meaning of the song: http://theboot.com/lee-brice-love-like-crazy-lyrics/

description: “Sorry Not Sorry” is an anthem towards Demi’s haters. In it, Demi confidently shows themselves off to their haters, which makes them feel annoyed that they’re (Demi) looking and feeling so good and they’re not. The track is lead single from their sixth album, Tell Me You Love Me.  The single was teased by Lovato and their team through cryptic updates on their social media accounts with the hashtag #SNS.  The song peaked at #6 on the Billboard Hot 100, which made it Demi Lovato’s highest career peak, besting their #9 peak of 2009’s “This Is Me.”

description: “Sober” is a single from Demi Lovato. A lyric video was uploaded to her official Youtube channel.  The song provides an open confession about facing recent challenges regarding her six-year sobriety. She made her achievement public on Twitter in March 2018:  https://mobile.twitter.com/ddlovato/status/974142838735884294?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw&ref_url=http%3A%2F%2Fpopcrush.com%2Fdemi-lovato-celebrates-6-years-sober%2F  However, the lyrics indicate how she may have possibly relapsed; her prior battle with addiction included the use of prescription drugs, cocaine, and alcohol.  Her 2017 documentary, Simply Complicated, depicts her mixed struggle with addiction, bipolar disorder, and childhood experiences which have shaped her life and influenced her journey through fame and fortune.  https://giphy.com/gifs/demilovato-l4Ep3I9jWu72K1wty

description: “Stone Cold” is the third single of the album Confident, released on 9 October 2015. Unlike the previous two singles, it’s a tender ballad about wishing an ex the best in another relationship.  Demi Lovato played the song for the first time live during her performance at the Highline Ballroom in New York on 29 September 2015.  Demi Lovato told Complex in a 2015 interview that “Stone Cold” is her favorite song off of the album. “I want the Grammy committee to hear [that song],” she said, “so that one day they can see that—I know that I’m capable of getting there.”

description: “Tell Me You Love Me' is the title track of Demi Lovato’s sixth studio album Tell Me You Love Me. In the song, Demi Lovato shows her vulnerability and emphasizes the need for a relationship in her life. It then progresses to realizing that at the end of the day all you need, and what you will always have, is yourself.  The song was released as the first promotional single from Lovato'’s sixth studio album Tell Me You Love Me on August 23, 2017. It was then later released as the second single from the album on November 14, 2017.

description: For their first solo release in 18 months, American singer-songwriter Demi Lovato dropped the emotional track, “Anyone,” as their comeback single shortly before their debut performance of the song at the 62nd GRAMMY Awards. In the vulnerable ballad, Demi can be heard crying for help as they talk about wanting someone to be there through the tough times with them.  Speaking to Zane Lowe in an interview on Apple Music’s New Music Daily, Demi recalled that no one had helped them with their struggles back when they wrote and recorded the song days before her drug overdose back in July of 2018:   I almost listen back and hear these lyrics as a cry for help. [And] you kind of think, “How did nobody listen to this song and think, ‘Let’s help this girl’.”  [Back then,] I was recording [the song] in a state of mind where I felt like I was OK — but clearly I wasn’t. I even listen back to it and I’m like, “Gosh, I wish I could go back in time to help that version of myself.”   Lovato’s GRAMMY performance of the track was first teased back in December 4, 2019, via Instagram with the caption, “The next time you hear from me, I’ll be singing….” Weeks later, on January 14, 2020, their performance of the then-unnamed song was announced.  According to the ‘music insider’ who had correctly confirmed Lovato’s GRAMMY performance, the song will not serve as the lead single from their upcoming seventh studio album. This was previously pointed out by fans after discovering that the song has not been officially sent to radio.

description: “Let It Go” is featured on the soundtrack for the Disney film, Frozen a movie based on the Hans Christian Andersen fairytale The Snow Queen. This version plays over the closing credit sequence, with Demi Lovato singing. The version in the film is sung by Wicked’s Idina Menzel.

description: Atop a wave of melancholy, Lovato sings of a seemingly unrequited love causing her to feel isolated in heart break. As she bemoans her precarious situation, the “How to Love” rapper, Lil Wayne lends his lyrical prowess to the track. Its production is handled by DJ Mustard, featuring sparse, ambient synths in contrasts with a trap-inflected minimalist beat.  Lil Wayne is the only collaboration on the standard version of Demi’s sixth studio album.

description: In ‘'Tunnel Vision,’‘ Kodak raps about serving jail time, the corrupt prison system, and other issues he’s faced in the past. Metro Boomin and Southside provide the beat.  Before the song’s release, Kodak teased the track via live performances, on his Instagram, and in several videos that received more than 1 million views before the song officially dropped.  The “Tunnel Vision” music video shows Kodak standing in front of a burning cross—a reference to the KKK. The video also features a white man wearing a hat that says “Make America Hate Again", a nod to President Donald Trump’s campaign slogan, “Make America Great Again.” The man in the hat prepares to shoot a black man, but his gun fails, and the two come to blows. Finally, a little girl appears and shouts “Stop!” which brings the video to an end.

description: “No Flockin” finds Kodak Black bragging about the almighty dollar. No matter who, where, when or what, he’ll always have money on his mind.  This song was Kodak’s break-out hit. After receiving a buzz for his previous songs, “SKRT” and “Skrilla,” this was the one that led him to be known nation-wide.  The song was also featured in Episode 2 of Drake’s OVO Sound Radio. Before that, Drake was captured on video dancing to Kodak’s “SKRT,” blowing up his spot. However, in an interview with XXL, Kodak said that he didn’t care too much about the 6 God’s co-sign:  I heard about, but I didn’t know what that did. I just knew that was Drake, so… You trying to show you fuck with me or what? We ain’t never talked on the phone, like he was texting me and shit. I’m direct with it. So, if you’re trying to show me that you fuck with me, call me. Throw me on your album so I can get me some royalties.

description: On this track, Kodak Black and XXXTENTACION give their opinions on the media’s influence on public perception. They also discuss issues they have each faced with women in their respective lives. This South Florida collaboration is produced by London on da Track and CuBeatz.

description: Kodak Black enlists Offset and Travis Scott for “ZEZE,” a song on which the trio discusses their decadent lifestyles on the song. Produced by Chicago-native d.a. got that dope, this track heavily features steel drum instrumentation.  Following “If I’m Lyin, I’m Flyin” two weeks prior, this is Kodak’s second single since being released from jail in August 2018 and the second single from Dying to Live.  In early September 2018, Kodak posted a now-deleted short clip of him and Travis Scott dancing to the song’s instrumental in the studio. This video became a viral sensation known as the #WaitingChallenge that inspired numerous memes. Kodak later posted another video of just himself dancing to the instrumental.  Kodak performed during the Florida A&M University homecoming festivities on October 5, 2018, and announced the song’s name and release date. One day before the song’s release, Kodak posted the cover art, which revealed that Offset was on the song, which was previously unknown. The song was released as expected on October 12, 2018.  The official music video was released on November 23, 2018. Travis Scott directed the video by himself. The video depicts the three rappers having a problem with the original film director, and hence things are the way they are. It is basically a behind-the-scenes twisted video, showing the three under a green screen and editing their effects.

description: “SKRT” is the sound that Kodak Black’s tires make when driving away from a sticky situation.  The song was released in 2014, but the track only started gaining momentum in late 2015, after receiving Drake’s highly coveted cosign—on the sixth episode of OVO Sound Radio and on his Instagram account.  https://instagram.com/p/9NIha_jQGu/?taken-by=champagnepapi  Despite the impact Drizzy had on introducing “SKRT” to the masses, Kodak told The Fader that he’s greater than the cosign: “Drake ain’t make me.”  The New Yorker wrote that “SKRT” is “a primal declaration of forward momentum.”  With this hook, Octave joins other young rappers who have rejected an old-school emphasis on lyrical variety, individualism, and personal catharsis. (Remember how he feels about school?) These are the devices that helped turn Kanye West and Eminem into stars; Octave and peers like Silentó and Desiigner have been castigated by some

description: “There He Go” is the first single dropped by Kodak Black since he was released from jail on December 1st. By December 3rd he was back on his grind, recording new music.  Some of the recording process for this song was posted on Snapchat (JBlack1K) in early December, as well as the video shoot for another unrecorded track.

description: Kodak Black takes us to the trap in his new video for “Skrilla.” In the video we see how infectious his live performance is and the harsh realities of life in South Florida. The buzzing Broward County, FL trapper has been making noise on the scene and has even earned a Drake co-sign.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9FipWCyIF4Y

description: “24 / 7 / 365” is an anecdote about Forrest’s encounter of a girl that he likes.  The song follows the chord progression and melody of the popular jazz song ‘Girl from Ipanema’.

description: ‘Good Day’ is a song produced and recorded by the music duo “Surfaces” in mid-2020. Rising to popularity via their hit song “Sunday Best,” Surfaces has gained much attention for their albums, including “Where the light is” and “Horizons.” Good Day is meant to be a feel good song, focusing on the greatness of their lives, presumably trying to give a nostalgic feel for listeners.

description: “Ransom” is the sixth single released by Lil Tecca. The music video was filmed by Cole Bennett and the track was produced by Nick Mira and Taz Taylor.  Throughout the song, the teenage artist shares some braggadocious lines about designer gear, diamonds, and riding in multiple luxury cars, like a Ghost and a Phantom.

description: “Love Me” serves as the twelfth track on Lil Tecca’s debut mixtape We Love You Tecca. On the track, Tecca shows his affection for a woman and states the benefits of contributing to a relationship with himself.  The song was released in October 2018 but made its official re-release through Tecca’s 2019 debut mixtape We Love You Tecca and serves as one of two 2018 songs added to the mixtape alongside September 2018 track “Count Me Out”.

description: Throughout “Did It Again,“ Lil Tecca raps about having sexual intercourse, making money, his exotic cars and traveling to foreign countries.  The track was originally released on January 21, 2019, becoming one of Tecca’s first hits: it eventually made it onto Tecca’s first mixtape We Love You Tecca, released on August 30, 2019.

description: This track concludes Virgo World as Lil Tecca raps about the lack of love in the world. He points out the clout-chasers, rapping about how everyone wants to be around him since he became famous.  Lil Tecca teased this song on March 25, 2020, with a Triller snippet he tweeted out. The track’s artwork hints towards it appearing on Tecca’s Virgo World, with the initials “VW” appearing on the motel sign on the cover.

description: On “Out of Luck,” Lil Tecca addresses his come-up in the music industry alongside the various negatives that come with his stardom. While specifically covering people changing their opinions on Tecca due to his newfound fame, the topics covered in the track are reminiscent to an Instagram livestream where he divulged his disdain with his recent come-up; following the success of his chart-smashing hit, “Ransom.”  Prior to the official release of the track, Tecca teased the track in an Instagram livestream, showcasing the majority of the track. He also teased a line of the chorus on Twitter pre-release.  On the same day of release–August 30th, 2019–an official music video released onto the Lyrical Lemonade YouTube channel, directed by Cole Bennett. Tecca and Cole have both worked together in the past, most notably in the music video for “Ransom,” which currently sits at over 200 million views on YouTube.

description: “Never Left” is the second promotional single off of Lil Tecca’s second mixtape, We Love You Tecca 2. Over a tropical instrumental, Tecca declares his return to hip-hop, alongside boasting the benefits of his position.  The track was first previewed on March 19, 2021 via Lil Tecca’s Instagram. The track released on May 6, 2021, accompanied by a Declan Kyle-directed music video the following day.

description: “Count Me Out” is Tecca’s ode to his expensive clothes and many girls that love him. He drops references to multiple expensive brands to signify his fame and wealth, whilst also touching on his haters in the past.  The track was released in September 2018, before eventually being featured on his debut mixtape We Love You Tecca in August 2019.

description: On “F.N,” emerging rapper Lil Tjay speaks about his friend snitching on him after getting caught partaking in gang activities. The eponymous track shows Tjay reflecting on his difficult upbringing and come up, while also boasting about the lavish lifestyle he now lives.

description: Lil Tjay has been through a lot of things in his life, like jail time, growing up in the hood and making bad decisions. With this song, he wants to show that there is more than just the life as a gang member and you can do other different things with your life, such as music.

description: On “Leaked,“ Lil Tjay raps an upbeat track on his newfound lifestyle. Dropping references to expensive brands, girls, and foreign cars, Tjay boasts about his fame and how he’s changed since his younger days. He reminisces on his life with crime prior to music, and how it’s changed his life for the better.

description: On “None Of Your Love,“ Lil Tjay raps a quick moving track about leaving girls in the past. The girl he raps about on the track originally didn’t want Tjay, but as soon as he blew up, she came back begging for him. Tjay knew she only wanted him for the fame, so he leaves her in his crime-filled past.  Additionally, he sarcastically samples and interpolates Justin Bieber’s January 2010 smash hit “Baby“ to show how he could’ve bought the girl anything if she was with him from the start.  Initially, the track wasn’t released on streaming services due to Tjay being unable to clear the “Baby” sample at the time so he, instead, released it to his YouTube on July 30, 2018.  More than two years later, on December 1, 2020, Tjay announced in an Instagram post that Bieber had finally granted him permission to release it on streaming services. It was released three days later on December 4, 2020.

description: Released on New Years Day in 2020, “20/20“ is Lil Tjay ode to the new decade. A play on the year 2020, “20/20“ is a reference to perfect vision. Tjay alludes to the fact that he has perfect vision for his future and his goals. He raps on his newfound fame and touches on his major goals for the upcoming year.

description: From the soundtrack for the 2013 film version of The Great Gatsby. The song was also featured in the second trailer released for the film, and used throughout the film as a motif of Gatsby and Daisy’s relationship.  According to Del Rey:  It was an honor to work with Baz Lurhmann on his amazing adaptation of one of the most extraordinary books ever written. The movie is highly glamorous and exciting; Rick Nowels and I were thrilled to write the song for the film.  “Young and Beautiful” was penned by Lana and the film’s director, co-writer, and co-producer Baz Luhrmann, for the soundtrack. Del Rey wrote an earlier version of the song for her Paradise EP, but re-worked it with Luhrmann after he heard it and decided it’d work great with the movie. The song served as the film’s kickoff single, and an “orchestral single” featuring an orchestra was also released. Its motif, as well as samples of it, can be heard throughout the film and its soundtrack.  A jazz version of the song, created by the Bryan Ferry Orchestra, can be heard in the background of the scene that introduces Daisy.

description: “Summertime Sadness” explores the atmosphere of a bittersweet summertime where Lana danced, cruised and felt electrified with a loved one. This song became a sleeper success from a dance remix by Cedric Gervais. The remix entered the Top 50 in the UK, the Top 10 on the Billboard Hot 100, and it topped the US Dance/Electronic songs chart.    The accompanying music video created great speculation over its underlying message. It depicts a tragedy where one woman (played by Lana Del Rey) jumps and the other (Jamie King), heartbroken, follows. Due to this, some claim that the song was written for a personal friend of Lana’s that committed suicide, or that it was written for a boyfriend that died years ago. However, there is absolutely no evidence of this, and many believe these speculations to be false in their entirety.

description: “Love” sees Lana treading her familiar themes of nostalgia for an idealized American past.  She muses on how this generation’s youth maintain a sense of wonder and empowerment in the face of adversity, due in part to the romanticized idea of love driving them forward. This alternative/indie rock track also touches upon the concept of loving others, as well as loving oneself. Gone are the self-destructive behaviors involving endless sex, drugs, and alcohol, which would offer her fun and pleasure that lasted until her next dose.  The official music video for the song was released on February 20th, 2017.

description: Not to be confused with the classic Iggy Pop song and album of the same name, the title track from Lana Del Rey’s fifth studio album, “Lust For Life” captures the essence of both Lana and Abel’s will to live. The moments when the two are doing what they love, with whom they love, remind them that life is worthwhile. In true Lana fashion, the song raids the larder of American pop culture, with nods to Iggy, ’60s girl groups, and even Billy Joel.  After earlier teasing the collaboration on Twitter, the track was officially released on April 19, 2017. It’s the first song written for her eponymous album, it marks Lana and The Weeknd’s fourth collaboration following “Prisoner,” “Party Monster” and “Stargirl Interlude.”  Lana initially worked with the Swedish hitmaker Max Martin on the track, before finalizing it with the help of Abel and Nowels.  The title Lust for Life was first used for Irving Stone’s 1934 biographical novel about Vincent Van Gogh. The phrase had also been used to name songs and albums by Iggy Pop, Drake, Childish Gambino, Girls and Heavenly.

description: “Born to Die” is described by Lana Del Rey as a “homage to true love and a tribute to living life on the wild side.” To quote Chelsea Hodson from New York Times, “In [Lana’s] melancholy world, to love is to live, so to love the wrong person is to be “born to die.”  It is the opening track from her studio album of the same name, released as the second single from the LP.  The music video was released on December 14th, 2011, receiving generally positive reviews. She spoke with MTV about its background:  For “Born To Die,” I wrote a treatment for it called “The Lonely Queen,” so that I would be in a setting that represented Heaven, sort of in like a remote castle in Romania. Walking through the halls flanked by tigers. And then she’d be flashing back to happier times in the arms of her love. And then Yoann Lemoine adapted that treatment and made it more doable. But I love that video. I really do. I can’t believe it turned out so beautifully. I spent a lot of time thinking about where I wanted it to go.

description: Released October 7, 2011 it served as the first single  off Lana Del Rey’s wildly successful debut studio album, Born to Die.  A popular song, “Video Games” is certified Gold by RIAA and garnering 218 million views on the YouTube music video.  The lyrics to this song are about two broken relationships in the singer’s past. “The verse was about the way things were with one person, and the chorus was the way I wished things had really been with another person, who I thought about for a long time” Del Rey said.  She also said the song’s meaning: “It’s a song about letting go of my musical ambitions and settling down into a simple life with a person I loved. We had a mutual love for the community of New York, art and hard work”.

description: The title track of Lana Del Rey’s sixth studio album speaks about an immature, pretentious poet. There’s a link to this song on “Venice Bitch,” the second song released from the album:  Paint me happy in blue Norman Rockwell  Del Rey shared a snippet of the song on Instagram on June 15th, 2019.  The song went on to earn a Grammy nomination for “Song of the Year” at the 2020 Grammys.

description: “drivers license” is a possible love ode about Rodrigo moving on from her previous relationship with Joshua Bassett, who is now supposedly dating Sabrina Carpenter, by doing the one last thing that she promised him—getting a driver’s license. The song showcases a brilliant balance of unfiltered outpouring and graceful specificity. Its accompanying music video spins a vivid portrait of Rodrigo as she drives aimlessly, longing for an ex-love.  The song was teased several times before its release in January 2021. On July 23, 2020, Olivia posted a snippet of the song on Instagram with the caption “wrote dis the other day. vv close to my heart. gonna call it drivers license I think lol.” She then posted another two snippets in December 2020, captioning them with “soon” and “sooner.” On January 4, 2021, she announced the song as her debut single.

description: “good 4 u” is the third single from Olivia Rodrigo’s debut studio album, SOUR. The song’s hook is laced with sarcasm, as Olivia sharply addresses her former partner for quickly moving on from their relationship without much of an issue or any care towards her at all. Like with her previous single, “deja vu,” Olivia again experiments musically, this time using drums and a guitar as primary instruments to emphasize her anger building up as the song progresses. Its angsty, pop-rock sound has drawn comparisons to 2000s acts like Paramore and Avril Lavigne.  In the music video, Olivia plays a high school cheerleader who is feeling distraught and vindictive over her former partner. She purchases a container of gasoline from a convenience store and appears to destroy her ex’s bedroom, setting it ablaze and causing it to flood. In the final shot, Olivia submerges herself into a lake with glowing red eyes—a subtle homage to the 2009 cult classic Jennifer’s Body in which Jennifer stares into the camera with bloodshot eyes while swimming in a lake.  Olivia first teased the song and its music video on April 26, 2021, by posting an Instagram photo showing her dressed as a cheerleader. On May 9, 2021, the song was revealed to be her next single in SOUR’s album trailer shown at theatrical screenings of In The Heights. The next day, its release was officially announced by Olivia on Instagram.

description: “deja vu” is the second single from Olivia Rodrigo’s debut studio album, SOUR, and her first release since the breakout success of her debut single, “drivers license.” This song finds Olivia at a different stage than its predecessor, with her beginning to move on from heartbreak. Olivia questions both the authenticity of her ex’s new relationship, as well as their emotions for their new girl. She also portrays feelings of pity towards this new girl, who is not experiencing anything unique with her now-lover.  Despite sharing similar themes, “deja vu” is musically different from “drivers license,” with a more upbeat melody. It shows influences from Taylor Swift, both melodically and lyrically, especially in the bridge and outro. The music video shows Olivia spying on another woman—played by actress Talia Ryder—and emulating her life out of adoration, including wearing nearly identical clothing, traveling to the same locations, and copying her actions. Eventually, the woman makes it known that she was aware of Olivia’s stalkery the entire time, and taunts her, leaving Olivia enraged.  In the week preceding its release, Olivia cleared all of her posts on her Instagram account and began posting a series of cryptic videos, showing various clips on an analog television. Three of these teasers were shared before the official announcement of the song on March 29, 2021. The day before its release, Olivia posted an acoustic snippet of the song on TikTok.

description: “All I Want” was written by Olivia Rodrigo for her role in the Disney+ show High School Musical: The Musical: The Series. In the fourth episode, Rodrigo’s character, Nini, sings the song while reflecting on her relationships with two boys, E.J. and Ricky.

description: On the aptly titled “traitor,” Olivia Rodrigo reflects on what went wrong in a past relationship, the feeling of being betrayed, and still missing what she had. She follows the same ideas in some of her other songs, such as her January 2021 breakout hit, “drivers license,” and “enough for you.”  The piano-driven ballad went trending upon release, with many fans and media speculating who the song was about.

description: “brutal” is Olivia Rodrigo’s punk-rock take on generational trauma. The production by Dan Nigro complements SOUR’s other tracks like “good 4 u” and “jealousy, jealousy.”  Rodrigo sings about the misleading promise of youth, including all the betrayals, disappointments, and challenges in our “golden years.”  The title hook, “it’s brutal out here,” references both the crude music industry and the difficult world that is adolescence. Olivia is learning to navigate both.

We don't talk much, but I just gotta say I miss you, and I hope that you're okay  [Bridge] Address the letters to the holes in my butterfly wings Nothing's forever, nothing was as good as it seems And when the clouds won't iron out And the monsters creep into your house And every door is hard to close [Outro] Well, I hope you know how proud I am you were created With the courage to unlearn all of their hatred But, God, I hope that you're happier today 'Cause I love you And I hope that you're okay
description: “hope ur ok” is the eleventh and final track on Olivia Rodrigo’s debut album SOUR.  She reminisces on some old friends that she’s lost contact with. She reminds them that nothing is as bad as it seems and wishes them well. She is proud of them and loves them. In the Sour Diary “Journal / Zine” Olivia said “Hope ur ok is the last song on the record. It’s a super special song to me & I love the stories it tells. I wrote most of it in my living room in early 2020, drawing inspirtation from some of my favorite country & folk artists. I think my favorite lines I’ve ever written are ‘hope he took his bad deal & made a royal flush’ & ‘hope you know how proud I am you were created with the courage to unlearn all of their hatred.’ I had so much fun making it & I hope it gives optimism to someone out there just like it did for me.”

description: Ava Max said in an interview with JAMS 96.3,  The track is about a girl who is misunderstood in a relationship. She thinks she’s going out of her mind and psycho. But in reality, she’s just a strong, independent female. In the end, the guy loves all of her sides – sweet, psycho (as he likes to call it).  A music video for the song was released on August 27, 2018. It was directed by Bengali-American filmmaker Shomi Patwary. Ava Max said in the same interview that it takes the song to a crazy place because of her love of theatrics.  Ava Max appeared on Genius' series Verified to explain the meaning of the song. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p9NSpo-qtv0  “Sweet but Psycho” peaked at #1 in 12 countries, including the UK. After spending several weeks on the Billboard Bubbling Under Hot 100, it went up to #87 in the last week of December. It peaked at #37 as of the week ending January 19.

description: “So Am I” is the follow-up single by Ava Max after her 2018 Platinum breakout hit, “Sweet but Psycho”.  The electro-pop song details the tale of empowerment on how Ava relates to being different and how those differences makes everyone unique.  In an interview, Ava Max said that it’s  About what makes people unique and different from each other. It’s about loving yourself, being different, being an outcast and not fitting in the format that society wants to put us in — just celebrating what really makes you different. Whenever I’m feeling down, I remind myself that my flaws make me perfect, because in reality there is no perfect."

description: “Kings & Queens” is a song by Ava Max, released on March 12, 2020 as a single from her album Heaven & Hell.  The song initially went through around 10 iterations, which included different melodies and production, before the final version was completed. Ava stated that “Kings & Queens” is about how it would be a better place if queens ruled the world and likened it to her previous song “So Am I”, acknowledging that it contained a similar message about empowerment.

description: “Salt” is an upbeat self-empowerment anthem about moving on from a past relationship by American singer-songwriter Ava Max. She uses “salt” as a metaphor for tears because they taste salty. By saying she is “all out” of it and “not gonna cry,” she tells the listener that she has moved on from her past relationship.  The song was first posted on Ava’s YouTube and SoundCloud account on July 27, 2018. Days after it’s release — on July 31, 2018 — she took to Instagram to talk about the song.  “Salt” is one of my favorite songs and I’m super excited to release it into the world!!! For now, it’ll just be up on my YouTube Channel and my SoundCloud (cuz I couldn’t wait any longer).  The song was officially released later on December 13, 2019.

description: Almost a year after its initial release, “Not Your Barbie Girl” took off thanks to video sharing platform TikTok, giving Ava Max a career boost.  The song uses the melody and lyric structure of Danish pop group Aqua’s satirical 1997 song Barbie Girl, but abandons its irony to opt for a more straight ahead message supporting womens' right to control who they consent to touch their bodies.

description: “Who’s Laughing Now” is a song by Ava Max. It was released on July 30, 2020 as the sixth official single from her upcoming debut studio album Heaven & Hell.                                                                                                                                                                        “Who’s Laughing Now” is the second song on the “Side B: Hell” side of Ava Max’s debut album, indicated by the track-list mistakenly put on image of the cassette tape from the official merch website before being taken down at a later point in time.                                                                             Currently releasing: September 18th 2020

description: “Torn” is a song by Ava Max. It was released on August 19, 2019 and the official music video was released on August 27, 2019.  Billboard described the song as a “disco-infused dance track where the star sings about the internal struggle of wanting to leave, while also wanting to stay with her lover.” The song was included on Vogue’s “34 Best Songs of 2019” list, where Christian Allaire stated that the song “earworms its way into [his] head at least once a day”.

description: On “WITHOUT YOU,” The Kid LAROI portrays what a love-hate relationship looks like, communicating his feelings towards a girl on the track while dealing with the struggles of a heartbreak.  LAROI sings over a slow, guitar-based instrumental produced by frequent collaborator and producer Omer Fedi, as well as Blake Slatkin.

description: This song was first previewed by The Kid LAROI in a TikTok video. In the song, he name-drops the famous TikTok personality Addison Rae. Through her popularity, LAROI’s TikTok video went viral on the platform, amassing 1.4 million views in 19 hours. Addison also created her own TikTok video with the song, which amassed over 8 million likes, furthering the popularity of the song even more.  LAROI announced in a tweet on March 13, 2020, that the song would be dropping “tomorrow.” However, he retracted that statement in another tweet later that day, revealing the release would be delayed a week so it could drop on major streaming platforms at the same time.

description: “TELL ME WHY” is a promotional single off of The Kid LAROI’s debut album, F*CK LOVE. Over an Internet Money-produced instrumental, LAROI pours out his emotions as he mourns his friends and family who have passed away.  The track is likely a tribute to his close friend and mentor, Juice WRLD who unfortunately passed away on December 8, 2019, due to a substance-induced seizure.  The track was initially previewed at an opening of Lil Tjay’s tour in early 2020, however, was previewed many times afterward. The single’s release was accompanied by a music video directed by Cole Bennett.

description: The Kid LAROI enlists Lil Tecca for “Diva,” where the duo flex the benefits of their recent success, but also acknowledge the fake love they receive as a result of it.  The song was first premiered in Sydney, Australia in November of 2019 when LAROI was the opening act for Juice WRLD’s Death Race For Love Tour.

description: On “F*CK YOU, GOODBYE,” The Kid LAROI and Machine Gun Kelly dive into their familiar relationship issues, as LAROI makes clear his discontent with his partner and his want to end their relationship. The two communicate their feelings over a guitar-based trap beat.  An early version of the song leaked in summer 2020 and was featured in episode 2 of the trailer for F*CK LOVE (SAVAGE), seemingly confirming its placement on the project.

description: On “SO DONE,” The Kid LAROI sings about his frequented topics such as love and the struggles that come with it, noting how he isn’t ready for love after a toxic and broken relationship. LAROI continues the theme of his recently released mixtape F*CK LOVE, making it clear that he’s “so done“ with love and pain.  “SO DONE“ was originally speculated to be an addition to F*CK LOVE, but, for unknown reasons, did not make the final tracklist.  On October 9, 2020, LAROI teased the release of the track alongside a Cole Bennett directed Lyrical Lemonade video on his Instagram story.

description: “NOT FAIR” sees The Kid LAROI detail a variety of familiar topics including rejection and tough relationships. The song features vocals from American singer Corbin, marking the first collaboration between the two artists.  LAROI first previewed the track on a Caffeine live-stream on May 21, 2020.  The third verse was originally previewed alongside Ohio-based rapper Trippie Redd. However, to the discontent of many, he did not end up appearing on the song.

description: AJR’s “Weak” is about trying to resist your urges. The song comes off AJR’s 2016 EP, What’s Everyone Thinking.  The band told All Access Music: “The goal of this EP was to address what everyone is thinking, but no one is saying.”

description: “Bang!” is a single from American pop band AJR speculated to be on Neotheater (Deluxe Edition), set to release on February 12th, 2020.  Following a month-long hiatus from social media, AJR teased the song via their Community text messaging service by revealing an image of the cover art. On February 2nd, they announced Bang! officially. On February 7th, AJR posted a 15 second snippet of “Bang!” on Instagram with reversed audio. https://www.instagram.com/p/B8RzumQpBoa/?igshid=8i9b3bep4gne

description: “Sober Up” is the fourth track on AJR’s second album titled The Click, and features singer-songwriter Rivers Cuomo.  In an interview with Billboard Pop Shop talked about what the song was about and what it was like to work with one of their favorite artists, Rivers Cuomo. Being a huge fan of Rivers for their entire career, they were floored to when he complimented their song, “Weak”. They added that they thought the appeal to “Sober Up” from a fan’s perspective must have been from the universal theme of simplistic times in a person’s life.  We did our first couple of semesters at Columbia, we were experiencing the whole college vibe, going to parties and doing that sort of thing. And then there was a time where we just started getting depressed a little bit. We started getting sad because we felt a little bit too grown up, because one of the things we kind of pride ourselves on is staying young and having that little-kid experience.

description: “Burn The House Down” is a politically-charged single by the indie pop band AJR. The original version of the song was used as the theme song for director Morgan Spurlock’s documentary, Super Size Me 2: Holy Chicken! They wrote it once they watched it and said:  We were blown away after watching the film, and we immediately connected with Morgan’s passion as an underdog trying to shed light on this corrupt giant […] We wanted to create a song that captured that passion. If enough underdogs band together, real change can happen, and we wanted to help inspire that change in “Burn the House Down.”

description: “Netflix Trip” is the third-last song of AJR’s The Click, based around TV Series The Office.  Band member Ryan explained:  “Netflix Trip” is the one I connect to the most. It’s a song about The Office, the T.V show. That was the first song we wrote for this album, actually, two years ago. We name checked a lot of things and tried to go places with the music that hadn’t been done. We’re enormous fans of the show and have been for like 10 years. The song is basically tracing different moments in my life, like my eighth grade graduation and when my grandpa died, and equating what season I was on in that moment in my life and how the show molded me.

description: “100 Bad Days” is the first single from AJR’s third album Neotheater. Band member Jack Met mentioned in an interview that the track touched on their most frequently used mantra, “this is going to be a good story.”  The trio told Billboard:  As a band, and as guys in their twenties, most of our experiences end in rejection, failure, and bad days. We wanted to write a realistic look at that… what doesn’t kill you doesn’t always make you stronger. But what doesn’t kill you always makes you more interesting.”

description: “Way Less Sad” is the twelfth track off of AJR’s newest album, “OK ORCHESTRA”. The song is the band’s way of looking into the world, trying to shine a brighter and less cynical light on the brothers surrounding.  Track 12 of the 13 track album “OK ORCHESTRA” discusses the trios New York life, and tries to paint a vibrant picture of modern societal norms.  The song makes reference to cancel culture, toxic environments, and ones inability “sleep at night” with the demons that loom over us.  In terms of lyrics, the tone itself is a more sincere look at the people that stand on the spinning globe, and the applications and lifestyle they choose compared to AJR themselves.

description: “Selfish” is the official second single to Madison’s debut album, Life Support. Madison confirmed the song in a tweet on Twitter.  On 10 February she posted another snippet on her Twitter, which was followed by the release of the music video on Valentine’s Day, February 14.

description: “Dead” is a song by American singer Madison Beer, recorded for her debut extended play, As She Pleases. It was released on May 19, 2017, as the lead single from the EP, alongside a lyric video.

description: “Say It to My Face” is a track by singer-songwriter Madison Beer that was released on November 3, 2017. The track’s main theme is to stand up for oneself and demand to be treated with respect.

description: Following the release of her As She Pleases – EP in February, Madison Beer returned to share a dark new song entitled “Hurts Like Hell.”  Prior to its official release, Madison teased the song on social media: https://twitter.com/madisonbeer/status/1059505842607792128  The song was co-written by pop-star Charli XCX and featured Migos member Offset. Madison expressed the song’s writing process to Paper Magazine saying:  Charli XCX is one of the writers on it. She was so incredible to work with, and we had so much fun. I wanted to do something… that we kind of were like, when you break up with someone you hope they see you doing really well, and I hope it hurts like hell. I hope you realize that you should have given me the love that I deserve, and that you messed up. Offset’s verse was really important, that he captured that as well. I wanted to make sure it felt like we were both ganging up on the same person, and that we were both talking to the same guy. It came out exactly how we wanted it to you. I’m just really proud of it.  The music video for “Hurts Like Hell” was released on November 14 and featured Beer playing a witch. She was shown using magic to take revenge on an abusive man before getting caught up in a witch hunt. It was co-written and executively produced by Beer, who in a press release said:  I had such a clear vision of what I wanted to do for this video. I was inspired by witchcraft and felt that it perfectly fit with the theme of the song, which is about teaching someone a lesson.

description: “Dear Society” is a single by pop singer Madison Beer. The single has been teased in interviews and a snippet which was posted to her Instagram on April 17, 2019 simply with the caption “may”. Madison has said the song is about social media and how our society perceives and is perceived.

description: Madison Beer refers to her wanting to do “As she pleases”, a constant theme throughout her EP. The person she talks about in the song is interested in fulfilling his sexual desires, despite his persistence, Madison insists she does not want to go home with him. She asks for respect and for the person to not objectify her and treat her like shes a game or a toy.

description: The song title “Tyler Durden” is a reference to a character in the cult classic 1999 film and 1996 novel Fight Club played by Brad Pitt. Tyler Durden and the unnamed narrator who suffers from insomnia form an underground fighting club.    Madison has called Fight Club her favorite film https://twitter.com/madisonbeer/status/883182383234600962 and the film was likely influential to her while creating her first EP As She Pleases, as she posted several images from the movie to Instagram throughout 2017 as she worked on her EP: https://www.instagram.com/p/BbatSoPj5RG/?taken-by=madisonbeer https://www.instagram.com/p/BVp-OtbjOtG/?taken-by=madisonbeer https://www.instagram.com/p/BUtDkIxjrQm/?taken-by=madisonbeer
