description: The lead single from the highly anticipated follow-up to 1989 takes shots at several unnamed rivals, who most fans suspect to be Kanye West, Kim Kardashian West, and Katy Perry — see this video for more. The song’s themes are of revenge and rebirth into a smarter, stronger person. It sees Swift move in a new sonic direction, incorporating electropop and an unexpected interpolation of the 90s hit “I’m Too Sexy” on the chorus.  In the week leading up to the track’s release, Swift cleared all previous social media presence and released three videos of a snake’s tail, body, and head; most considered this a reference to her widespread reputation as a “snake.” She then revealed the album title and cover, and announced the release dates for both the album and the single.  A short preview of the music video was aired on Good Morning America the morning of the song’s release; the clip was later posted to Swift’s social media accounts and official site. The full video premiered during the MTV Video Music Awards on August 27th, 2017 — check out the analysis here! The video made both VEVO and YouTube history, amassing the most views within 24 hours in history on both platforms.  On the reputation Album Release Party, Taylor revealed that “Look What You Made Me Do” started out as a poem:  It actually started with just a poem that I wrote about my feelings, and it’s basically about realizing that you couldn’t trust certain people, but realizing you appreciate the people you can trust. Realizing that you can’t just let everyone in, but the ones you can let in, you need to cherish. And it had all the verses in it, just basically as is.  Later on, after the music video of “Look What You Made Me Do” was released, Taylor herself came out to explain the true meaning behind the LWYMMD music video:

description: “betty” touches on the aftermath of “august,” which describes a summer love that was doomed from the start. Listeners learn that while the summer affair was going on, the speaker, James, was still dating their classmate, Betty.  The song takes a more feminist approach, portraying the narrator as a person named James who can’t own up to their mistakes, all while Betty flourishes on her own and recognizes her worth.  Sonically, the song exudes a strong sense of nostalgia, delivering production and instrumentals reminiscent to Taylor’s earlier projects like Fearless and Speak Now, both of which were records written by Taylor in her similarly naïve adolescence.  “betty” is believed to be the third part of folklore’s “Teenage Love Triangle,” told from the point of view of James. The storyline is preceded by “cardigan” and “august.”  Interestingly, James' gender is never explicitly stated—James and Inez (mentioned in the pre-chorus) are, in fact, the names of Blake Lively and Ryan Reynolds‘ eldest daughters—leading some to believe that James could be a girl and that the Teenage Love Triangle is, in fact, a sapphic love story.  However, Taylor confirmed James' gender while explaining the song on country radio:  [James] has lost the love of his life basically and doesn’t understand how to get it back…Everybody makes mistakes, everybody really messes up sometimes and this is a song that I wrote from the perspective of a 17-year-old boy. I’ve always loved that in music you can kinda slip into different identities and you can sing from other people’s perspectives. So that’s what I did on this one–and I named all the characters in this story after my friends' kids."

description: This star-studded track is the sole collaboration on reputation. Before it was announced, “Eddie” and “Future” were written in graffiti in certain shots of the “…Ready For It?” music video.  “End Game” revolves around the idea of Taylor wanting to be her lover’s soulmate. While she never mentions who this person is, the Internet seems to be convinced that since he has a huge “reputation,” he must be Tom Hiddleston, whom Taylor was in a relationship in 2016, or Joe Alwyn, her boyfriend as of the song’s release. Through the lyrics, Taylor hopes that the “drama” revolving around her doesn’t keep this guy from being with her because they’ve already been so close.  Taylor previously worked with Ed Sheeran on her 2012 track “Everything Has Changed,” on which Ed sang the second verse. This is her first collaboration with Future and her overall third collaboration with a rapper, following the remix of her track “Bad Blood,” which featured Kendrick Lamar., and “Both of Us” by B.o.B., featuring Swift.  The track was released as the 3rd single off the album and sent to contemporary hit radio on December 3, 2017 in the United States. The music video was released on January 11th, 2018.

description: “Dior” is Pop Smoke’s most popular solo song to date. It is part of both of Pop’s mixtapes, Meet the Woo and Meet the Woo 2. It was also included as a bonus track on Pop’s posthumous debut album, Shoot for the Stars Aim for the Moon. It debuted and peaked at #30 on the Billboard Hot 100, making it Pop’s highest-charting song.  On February 19, 2020, Pop was tragically shot and killed. The song became popular after his death and re-entered the Billboard Hot 100 in the following week.  The track’s official music video was released on September 3, 2019.

description: “Mood Swings“ sees Pop Smoke reuniting with Bronx rapper Lil Tjay for a slow-moving track. The two take turns dropping references to their women and expensive items to boast about their lifestyle with fame.  Pop and Tjay made this track the same night they made their October 2019 hit “War,“ a track which was featured on Pop’s 2020 mixtape, Meet The Woo 2.

description: Featuring hard-hitting production from UK drill producer 808Melo, “Welcome to the Party” is a drill banger and the breakout hit for Brooklyn-native rapper Pop Smoke.  The track served as the second single to his debut mixtape Meet the Woo. Released on April 23, 2019, the song would go onto gain widespread attention and popularity and remixed from many artists in the rap game, including the likes of: ASAP Ferg, Dave East, Kiing Shooter, Meek Mill, Pusha T and Rico Nasty. Pop Smoke would release two official remixes however, with fellow rappers in Nicki Minaj and Skepta.

description: “For the Night” is the 3rd track off of the late Pop Smoke’s album, Shoot for the Stars Aim for the Moon. Besides being off a highly anticipated album, the song was also highly popularized due to a Tiktok dance surrounding the song.  This song marks the first collaboration between Pop, Lil Baby, and DaBaby. On a beat produced by CashMoneyAP and MIKE DEAN, the trio talk about their nighttime activities, how they act around women, and their now-lavish lifestyles. The song points to how the rappers don’t want a long-term relationship, wanting only a companion, “For the Night”.

description: “Got It On Me” samples and interpolates executive producer 50 Cent’s May 2003 track “Many Men (Wish Death)” and features many of the same themes as the iconic track, including Pop wishing for mercy from those who are out to attack him.  The song was featured in the album trailer for Shoot for the Stars, Aim for the Moon on June 10, 2020, and its title was confirmed via Shazam.  The verses were taken from Pop’s Power 106 Freestyle, shown here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x1YHynM540A

description: “What You Know Bout Love” was first leaked to the internet in late February 2020 shortly after the untimely passing of the American rapper, Pop Smoke.  Smoke shares his more intimate side and heartfelt love for a special woman who has came into his life on this track.

description: The second single from WHEN WE ALL FALL ASLEEP, WHERE DO WE GO?, “when the party’s over,” sees Billie putting some distance between her and her lover. It was described by the singer not as a sad song, but rather as more of an angry mood.  Its official release was first teased by Eilish’s brother (who also produced this track as well as many other Eilish songs), Finneas, on Twitter:  https://twitter.com/finneasoconnell/status/1051163190250196992?s=21  Eilish later shared the official release in an Instagram post. In a later Instagram story, Eilish also confirmed the release of a music video in addition to the Spotify Vertical Video, saying:  you are not even READY for the official video  The video, released on October 25th, 2018, was inspired by fan artwork. It features Eilish crying thick, inky black tears, and reached #1 on YouTube trending in several countries, including the US.  The song was first performed live on the 30th of January 2018 at The Tuning Fork in Auckland, New Zealand, and stayed in the setlist of the singer’s second tour, the “Where’s My Mind Tour.”

description: “everything i wanted” sees Billie recalling a nightmare she experienced where she committed suicide and saw all her friends and fans turn their backs on her. The lyrics showcase Billie’s strong relationship with her brother FINNEAS, as he’s the one she goes to for support when dealing with these types of problems.  The song is Billie Eilish’s first single released after her debut album, WHEN WE ALL FALL ASLEEP, WHERE DO WE GO?. The song was announced on November 11, 2019 via Twitter and Instagram stories. It had also been previously teased via Twitter on November 5th, 2019. On November 12, 2019, one day before its release, Eilish teased a 12-second snippet of the track via Instagram. A year before the track’s release, an eight second instrumental clip of “everything i wanted” could be heard in the background of one of Eilish’s Instagram stories.

description: “bad guy” is a playful, bass-heavy track that sees Eilish taunting her lover, flaunting her tough nature while questioning his own.  It was first proven to exist after Eilish teased a snippet of the track on her Instagram story.  In an interview with PopBuzz, Eilish referred to the track, stating she knew from the beginning that “bad guy” would open the album.  On the same day as the album’s release, the official music video was uploaded to YouTube. The beginning of the video also contains “!!!!!!!”, the intro of WHEN WE ALL FALL ASLEEP, WHERE DO WE GO?. Billie confirmed that the song would be receiving a music video with a comment on Instagram under a fan post.  On August 19th, the song reached #1 on the Billboard Hot 100 making her the first person born in the 21st century to have a #1 and dethroning Lil Nas X’s “Old Town Road”, who held the #1 spot for 19 consecutive weeks. Lil Nas X congratulated Billie on her achievement through a tweet:  https://twitter.com/LilNasX/status/1163547042376900610  A remix featuring Justin Bieber was released on July 11, 2019.

description: On “idontwannabeyouanymore,” Billie Eilish faces her insecurities, addressing her lack of self-confidence and self-deprecating emotions.  Billie explained that the meaning of this song is directly opposite to the meaning of her other popular song, “COPYCAT.”  “COPYCAT” is basically about someone doing fucking everything you do. The idea of “idontwannabeyouanymore” was sort of like, exactly the opposite. You know, “COPYCAT” is like “you wanna be me so bad, I’m the shit” but really, no I’m not. And it’s like, you wanna be me. I look at the mirror over here, I don’t wanna be you.  https://youtu.be/-BzvCCzH-n0?t=31     In January 2019, thanks to the viral video of Eilish singing the track on Genius' Verified episode from May 2018, the 2017-released song soared up the Genius charts. A Genius article gives a full breakdown of the story.

description: According to a January 2019 Alternate Press article, “bury a friend” is written from the perspective of a monster under Billie Eilish’s bed. The track details a confusing relationship with this ‘entity’ and ambiguously sets her up to be the monster itself.  A snippet of “bury a friend” was teased by Eilish on her Instagram page, as well as on Twitter and YouTube, on January 28, 2019. The visual depicts Billie’s face being grabbed by several gloved hands that reach in from off screen, until the closing lyrics and album title are displayed. She posted on Instagram the following day, announcing her debut album would be titled WHEN WE ALL FALL ASLEEP, WHERE DO WE GO?  The song itself features a Prismizer effect, which manipulates pitch and frequency characteristics to achieve a choral phase, much like Eilish’s other January release, “WHEN I WAS OLDER.” Her friend Mehki Raine makes a few short appearances on the song and seems to be talking directly to Eilish.  Many fans believe an episode of sleep paralysis, which Billie shared on her Instagram story, was one of the inspirations for the song. In a reply to an Instagram comment, Eilish alluded to the validity of this theory.    On February 22, 2019, Billie posted a video in collaboration with YouTube Music, where she and her brother Finneas explain the meaning behind the song and the creation of it. When asked by Radio Energy for her favorites from the album, Eilish chose “bury a friend” as one of them.

description: “i love you” is a soft acoustic ballad that explores the struggles and feelings from a complicated relationship. The song’s chorus features vocal harmonies by her brother, FINNEAS.  On May 13th, 2018, she teased a 15-second snippet of the demo to her fans. This snippet was re-posted to her Instagram story on January 2nd, 2019, where she confirmed it to be the twelfth track on her debut album. However, it was replaced by “listen before i go,” becoming the thirteenth track instead.  When asked by Radio Energy for her favorites on the album, Eilish listed “i love you” as one of them, citing the track as, “still one of my favorite songs I’ve ever written in my life.”  In an interview with PopBuzz, Eilish confirmed that the final three song titles on the album were intended to form a sentence, beginning with “listen before i go,” then “i love you,” ending on “goodbye.” The sentence was initially supposed to begin with a track titled “i dont know, i just wish i wasnt breathing,” but Eilish stated that the song was never completed, and therefore could not be included on the record.  At 4 minutes and 52 seconds, “i love you” is the longest track of Eilish’s discography.  Many have also pointed out similarities between the chorus of “i love you” and Leonard Cohen’s iconic song, “Hallelujah”.  The song’s Spotify artwork was done by @junkie.cowboy on Instagram.

description: As Eilish explained in an Instagram livestream, “wish you were gay” is about how it felt for her to be rejected by a boy she liked. At the time, Billie thought he didn’t like her because she was a “shitty person.“ She wanted some other reason for him not liking her, such as him being gay. Ironically, after she wrote this song, she found out he really was gay after all.  Eilish made an Instagram post with a small snippet of the song the day before its March 4, 2019, release.  She also revealed on Instagram that it took her three years to release the song once it was written. However, a demo version circulated for many years before its official rerecording and professional release in 2019.  Eilish addressed accusations of homophobia in a Pop Buzz interview.

description: “New Rules” is about moving on from an ex and how you need to stay away from them. The narrator needs to treat themselves like they would a friend with their own advice.  The music video premiered on July 7, 2017. After seeing covers of the song and recreations, Dua Lipa was inspired to release a new video with a compilation of the covers. At the end, she expressed her gratitude:  Thank you so much for being a massive part of ‘#DuasNewRules.’ It feels like yesterday I was uploading covers on YouTube, and now to have all of you guys covering me is absolutely everything. You guys are the best.  “New Rules” became Dua Lipa’s first number one single in the United Kingdom and Ireland.    “New Rules” peaked at #6 on Billboard’s Hot 100 Chart, marking Dua Lipa’s first top-10 hit in America. On July 3rd, 2018, “New Rules” ended it’s 48 week run on the Billboard Hot 100, making it her first single to spend the most weeks on the Hot 100.

description: “Don’t Start Now” is the lead single from Dua Lipa’s  second studio album, her second release of 2019, following “Swan Song” in January. The disco-inspired track kick starts Dua’s new era, first alluded to when a blonde-haired Dua took to social media on October 23, posting a snippet of the track, with the caption “Miss me?”  She went on to announce the song on October 24, 2019, posting another snippet of the track, before revealing its album art. Less than 24 hours prior to its release, one lucky fan was given a preview of the track on BBC Radio 1. Hours later, a Snapchat filter which features a snippet of the song was released to the public alongside a tweet with information on the song and music video’s worldwide premiere.  Ed Millet of TaP Management, whom Dua is managed by, described the track as “more upbeat and dance-y” in an interview with Variety (October 2019).  After the release of the song, Dua previewed a snippet of the music video via a trailer hours before the official music video was released.

description: “IDGAF” is the fifth track on Dua Lipa’s self-titled debut album. The song was first previewed via Instagram on May 1, 2017. Lyrically, it serves as a kiss-off to a creeping ex who’s trying to latch on to fame. IDGAF is an acronym for “I don’t give a fuck”, which appears in the song’s chorus. Dua announced that the song would be released as the album’s seventh single on January 12, 2018.

On August 22nd, 2016, her 21st birthday, she unveiled that the single would be released that Friday.  https://twitter.com/DUALIPA/status/767700943802630145

description: With themes of space travel and excitement, “Levitating” is a joyful ode to the often-quick process of falling in love. Originally included on Dua Lipa’s 2020 album, Future Nostalgia, the song found new wind towards the end of 2020 and the beginning of 2021 with a DaBaby assisted remix that only served to heighten the songs popularity and skyrocket its crossover appeal.  The addictive beat, popularly said to “have crack in it” throughout the internet due to its catchy appeal, was made by Stuart Price and KOZ.

description: “Break My Heart“ is the fourth single from British singer-songwriter Dua Lipa’s “disco-orientated” second studio album, Future Nostalgia, where Dua finds herself questioning her relationship choices.  It was first revealed in an interview with SunriseOn7 on March 2, 2020, that the upbeat disco-pop song will be pushed as the album’s third official single:  I’m really excited for [“Break My Heart”]. That’s gonna be the next song that everyone’s gonna hear. I just shot the video for it.  On March 18, 2020, the length of the track was revealed on iTunes, hinting that it could be released soon. A day later, Dua took to social media to share a line from the song with fans, as well as what seems to be a frame of an unannounced music video. Following the teaser, Dua unveiled the cover art for the single and its release date via social media. It was later revealed by Dua via her Instagram live that the song would drop two days earlier than planned — with the album’s release being moved up to occupy its March 27 release.  It is also worth noting that “Break My Heart” marks Dua’s first time collaborating with renowned producers The Monsters & Strangerz and watt.

description: “Be The One” is the first single from British artist Dua Lipa’s self-titled debut album, and on it she sings about trying to convince her lover to return to her despite the mistakes she’s made. The track was featured on Lipa’s debut album, which was released on June 2nd 2017 by Warner Bros.  Lipa described the song to NYLON Magazine:  For me, ‘Be The One’ is about self-belief, perseverance, and fighting for what you want. […] In this instance, it’s about a relationship, but really, this is an attitude I try to bring into everything in my life.  The music video was released Oct. 29, 2015, and it was directed and produced by Nicole Nodland, who also directed Lipa’s music video for her single “New Love.”

description: It was the day after my very first Award show, and I remember being completely overwhelmed. I walked into the studio with my producers, Paul and Jason, and they asked “What’s going on in your world? How has it been?”, it was the first time we had written since “How Can It Be.” I was feeling overwhelmed that much had happened the night before. How do I come back down to normal? How do I come back down to reality?  This brought up the issue of identity and trying to figure out how to exist when I feel like so many things were pulling me in so many different directions. We pretty quickly finished the writing and demo recording that day.  Over the course of two years of touring, I would sing “You Say” every night.  I remember starting to hear fans sing along to a song that had never been heard before. When it came time to make the record, it was a really fun process to have the challenge presented with something that I felt like I’d been living with. I felt like I got to a place of expressing this song exactly how I wanted to sing it.

He  said to look up, because he is showing the person he is there and in heaven, watching and guiding the person’s soul. description: Inspired by Psalm 37:24, “This Girl” is the story of Lauren comparing her spiritual life to a physical journey, specifically in how she finds God.  Though he may stumble, he will not fall, for the LORD upholds him with his hand.  Like most songs, “This Girl” gets its title from the chorus. Lauren explains that it goes deeper than that, saying it “holds hands” with the nickname that her grandfather used to call her growing up: “That Girl.”

description: We were on the road in Wichita, KS when this song first came together in 2019. I hardly ever write while touring, but this song came pouring out of us, though we were all experiencing vastly different seasons in our lives. Oftentimes, you write songs with a certain intent, feeling, and purpose. These lyrics might have meant one thing in the moment, but hold a completely different meaning now. Right then in Wichita, I loved how the crowd would engage and how it resonated with everyone — but the depth of this song and these lyrics didn’t strike me to the core right away.  This song means more to me now than it ever has.  I want people to listen to this song and be reminded that even when they don’t feel like themselves, they can find comfort in knowing that there are people who can see beyond their darkest moments. We need to remind others that they have an army of people standing behind them, supporting them through the best and worst of times. Whenever you feel doubt, angst, or uncertainty, know that you have people in your life who are there for you to lean on in every season.

description: “I Get the Bag” is a promotional single from Gucci Mane’s 13th studio album, Mr. Davis, where he teams up with an Offset-less Migos.  Takeoff and Quavo rap about their drug-fueled ways and Gucci brags about his wealth and his women. Gucci previously collaborated with Migos on their single, “Slippery” which shares similar flows on this song.

description: On “Both,” Gucci and Drake collaborate for the second time in 2016. The first being “Back on Road” released days after Gucci’s release from prison.  In the song, Gucci and Drake speak on multiple topics including Lil Yachty, luxury lifestyles, and stuff Drizzy doesn’t usually do: making reckless decisions from drinking and smoking.  The song debuted at No. 41 on the Billboard Hot 100, establishing a record on Drake’s career, earning his 132nd Hot 100 hit—tying Lil Wayne’s record for the most Hot 100 appearances by a solo artist.

description: “Curve” was officially released on September 13, 2017. It will serve as track 5 on Gucci Mane’s upcoming LP Mr. Davis.    The Weeknd has been teasing this collaboration for a couple weeks leading up to his Phase 2 Starboy Tour, where Gucci Mane is an opener.  NAV has confirmed he produced the song on Instagram. It is also co-produced by FrostADX.

description: The pinnacle of Gucci Mane’s work, “Lemonade” was the ultimate rap-pop crossover that poised him for a mainstream breakthrough.  “Lemonade” samples the song “Keep It Warm” by Flo & Eddie.

description: On “Met Gala,” Gucci Mane teams up with fellow Atlantan Offset for a song about the Met Gala, how girls want them now because they got money, & basically how rich they are.  Metro & Southside teamed up to make this beat.

description: “Truth” is a critically acclaimed (non) diss track from Gucci stemming from his years-long feud with fellow Atlanta rapper Jeezy.  The beef began when the two collaborated on Gucci’s 2005 track “So Icy,” which both rappers claim as their own song.  Later that year the beef took a deadly turn when Jeezy put a $10,000 bounty on Gucci’s ice cream cone chain in his song “Stay Strapped:”  Matter of fact, real talk nigga, I got a bounty on that shit nigga, ten stacks…to snatch that motherfucker off his neck  Five armed men, in an attempt to snatch the chain, broke into a home Gucci Mane was in. After a brief struggle, Gucci shot and killed one of the assailants, Pookie Loc, a rapper signed to Jeezy’s label. Weeks later, after the body was discovered buried by a middle school, Gucci Mane was charged with murder. This incident inspired these infamous bars from “Truth:”  Go dig your partner up, nigga, bet he can’t say shit And if you looking for the kid, I’ll be in Zone 6

description: The second single off of Glass Animals' debut album, ZABA, and the first to US alternative radio.  As described in an interview, it’s about “youth and naïvety and childishness”, and a love encounter gone wrong. All set to sexy, chill instrumentals.  “Gooey” was featured as the song for the closing credits of Magic Mike XXL.

description: “Youth” is about the nostalgia and the strange mix of happiness and sadness that swirls around it. It is sung from a parent to a child.  The song is the second single from Glass Animals' sophomore album How to Be a Human Being, and uses a melody similar to that of frontman Dave Bayley’s remix of Banks' “Drowning,” leading many fans to speculate that “Youth” was partly based on that song.

description: “Heat Waves” is the fourth single from UK band Glass Animals' third studio album Dreamland. The song features a melancholy tone but maintains high energy through its instrumental, with Dave speaking on remaining strong through vulnerable moments in your life and embracing your vulnerability.  The band first teased the track along their 2020 Déjà Vu Tour, as seen on the setlist for the Toronto show on the tour. Dave then teased the song’s release and chorus lyrics on the band’s subreddit on June 26, 2020. It was later premiered as Annie Mac’s Hottest Record in the World on BBC Radio 1 on June 29, 2020.

description: Glass Animals' first single off their sophomore album How to Be a Human Being features a more boisterous, raw, percussion-driven sound. The song appears to have once been called “Super Sonic Ray Gun” as a working title.  According to lead singer Dave Bayley, it’s about “a guy who was born a bit strange, and struggles to become part of society. Because of that, he spends more time alone in his own head, getting stranger, and it becomes an awful cycle of doom.”  The song is about the character seen in the top left of the album cover.  The guy, Chuck Rogers, has a fictional website that calls back to Internet days of Geocities and MySpace, in all of its eyebleeding glory.

description: “Pork Soda” is the fourth track off of Glass Animals' sophomore record How to Be a Human Being, as well as the source of the pineapple becoming a symbol of Glass Animals fandom.  According to Dave Bayley, the title came from a tattoo:  It was a giant pig, a stick figure pig, a really cool pig. It said pork soda in big scrawling letters, I thought it was the best tattoo I’ve ever seen. It was this woman, she gave us a load of gifts, it was amazing, 30 little glass animals. I saw her tattoo, and I was like, ‘that’s sick – why?’ And she was like, ‘I just like pork soda,’ and I thought that was really cool, it played into the mentality of the person in that song. I just really liked the phrase. It’s a drink. It’s a drink and it’s a meal, they put pork and cook it in coca cola in a stew. She says it’s the best meal and a drink.  Dave shared his photo of the pig tattoo on the band’s Facebook page:    This song, according to Genius, is about the man second from the left in the back row of the album cover.

description: “Season 2 Episode 3” (Album 2 Track 3) is the third track from Glass Animals’s sophomore record How To Be A Human Being.  The song release was accompanied by the following statement on Facebook:  everyone knows someone like the character from this song. someone who does nothing. all day. every day. there are lots of references to different psychedelic cartoons and old video games in this one. including adventure time. sonically we tried to make sounds that would have been floating around in the the character’s brain…sounds that could have been in those cartoons and video games. and there’s a line about mayonnaise

description: “Losin Control” is Russ' 49th single of 2015 and was released on November 9th, 2015. It also stands as Russ' most popular R&B performance, proving that he is not only a rapper and producer.  Russ wrote this song for his first girlfriend as an apology. He expressed his motive for creating the song in a tweet that was deleted moments after posting it, he explains:  I’m tryna to empathize that I understand why she’s fighting her feelings  In the first verse, he is actually telling the story of how he neglected his first girlfriend. His first girlfriend is the same girl that he raps about in a song released two months before this one, “First One”; it goes more into depth about the girl, their relationship, and what he did to push away the only girl who genuinely cared for him.  Due to the way Russ treated his ex, she now finds it hard to give her love and trust to another man. In the second verse Russ explains that the new guys intentions were nothing like his were. Even though the new guy is proving to her that he isn’t going to take her love for granted she still battles an internal conflict because of her relationship with Russ.      The official music video was released to YouTube on February 1, 2016. The video is directed by Edgar Esteves and features Russ himself, along with YouTube beauty vlogger Taylor Layne.

description: “What They Want” is Russ' 37th single. The song is a response to labels—Russ is saying he’s better off without them. On January 2, 2016, a little over four months after being released, “What They Want” reached its first million plays. People continued to listen and the song grew popularity, making it Russ' first song to reach 3 million plays.  https://twitter.com/russdiemon/status/722234150724452352  On May 3, 2016, the official music video for “What They Want” was released via Russ' YouTube. The video was directed by Edgar Esteves with help from Juanma Sierra. It also gained a spot on World Star Hip Hop a day after its release.  After the release of the music video, the song got recycled and gained more attention. And now the song is quickly reaching 4 million plays on SoundCloud alone. It also got to the “Hot Tracks” section on iTunes on May 6th, among artists like Drake, Migos, Desiigner, and more.  On the 15th of July 2017, Russ posted a video on his twitter and facebook of how he made the beat :  https://twitter.com/russdiemon/status/886072460013129728

description: “Pull The Trigger” is Russ’s 34th single of 2015.  Every song has been produced, written, mixed, and engineered by Russ himself. description: As the fourth single on Russ' debut album, “Do It Myself” sees Russ talking about solely taking over the game. In this song, Russ talks about labels hitting his line after fame, coming up, and more.  “Do It Myself” is Russ' 56th and final single of 2015 that was released on New Year’s Eve.

description: “Before He Cheats” sees Underwood teaching an unfaithful lover a lesson. As the third single from 2005’s Some Hearts, the track became the first country song in history to sell over two million digital copies, and won two Grammy awards, for Best Female Country Vocal Performance and Best Country Song. Since its release, it has been certified five times platinum by the RIAA, selling five million copies.

description: This song follows Underwood’s journey of coming to terms with herself and her difference of appearance after an accident. She fell on the steps of her home and had to receive 40-50 stitches on her face.  In “Cry Pretty”, she exposes her vulnerability and insecurities and gives power to them, empowering and enabling others to feel comfortable doing the same. She tells listeners to join her in embracing their emotions even when they aren’t “pretty”. It is common for people in this society both men and women, to suppress their emotions because they feel they will be viewed as weak or ugly if seen crying or under turmoil. She sends a message to those fans about how unrealistic it is for them to expect to be able to maintain an attractive appearance when going through distress and to embrace how they look. This song promotes healthy expectations, body love, anti-shame and general acceptance.

description: On the 6th of January 2018, “Champion” was officially previewed during the NFL Wild Card game between the Atlanta Falcons and Los Angeles Rams.  Carrie Underwood’s Instagram page also posted a clip previewing the song:    The first collaboration between 7-times Grammy Winner/Country superstar Carrie Underwood and rapper Ludacris leaked two days before its official release which was set for Friday January 12th.  Underwood has not released a solo single since she dropped “Dirty Laundry” from her 2015 album Storyteller back in September 2016. Her most recent collaboration was “The Fighter”  duet released in February 2017 and featured on Keith Urban’s Grammy-nominated Ripcord album.  The song will also be the first new music Carrie releases since revealing facial injuries caused after falling outside her Nashville home back in November 2017. She also revealed that the accident was much more serious than originally thought, resulting in “between 40 and 50 stitches” to her face.

description: “Love Wins” is a song by Carrie Underwood, released as the second single from her album Cry Pretty.  The song covers the aspect that we may feel that we’re all divided, but are connected by love.

description: When your car loses control on a snow-covered road, who do you turn to?  Released in 2005, the Brett James, Hillary Lindsey and Gordie Sampson penned “Jesus Take the Wheel” was a huge hit on both Country and Christian Billboard charts. Underwood took home Grammys for Best Country Song and Best Female Country Vocal, as well as the American Country Music Award for Single of the Year.

description: This chilling, vengeful tale of a young girl with an abusive, alcoholic father is the title track of American Country singer Carrie Underwood’s fourth studio album. Speaking to a group of Nashville journalists, the singer discussed naming the record after this song: “The first time I heard the song, I knew I had to have it and it was like, ‘That’s the title!’ Hopefully everyone will be blown away by the album. I think it’s pretty special. Hopefully it’s not just the title track but the feeling people will get when they listen to it.”

description: “Smoke Break” is the lead single from Carrie Underwood’s fifth studio album, Storyteller. The track, written with Hillary Lindsey and Chris DeStefano, premiered on August 20, 2015 at country radio and was digitally released on August 21.  Underwood announced “Smoke Break” and accompanying album Storyteller in a video posted to Facebook, in which she also described its meaning:  The song itself is … one of those story songs that I feel like everyone can relate to about how life is so hectic and it’s so nice if and when you actually get to kind of step away for a second. We all need that time to ourselves, to get to take a break.  According to USA Today, the track came to life while getting stuck working one of the other tracks on Storyteller:  We were writing and kept taking breaks to go outside because we were getting a little stuck on a song we were already working on. It was so beautiful outside, that we had a hard time focusing so we decided to write a song about taking breaks! “Smoke Break” seemed like a great title, so we ran with it!

description: Dropping amid ongoing political and cultural tumult and turmoil, Childish Gambino’s “This is America” appears to be a commentary on black life in America and American culture as a whole. It contrasts popular culture’s perception of black experience and its often brutal reality by juxtaposing happy, carefree choruses and dark, aggressive verses.  This contrast may also allude to the cyclical shifts in mood whenever there is a shooting in America. One second, the entire nation is in an uproar, the next, they are happy and unconcerned, placated by pop culture trends.  In the music video, directed by frequent Gambino collaborator Hiro Murai, Gambino portrays this comparison by dancing around gleefully with school-aged children, seemingly unbothered by the chaotic scenes of violence in the background. However, in the short film’s final scene, Gambino is seen running frantically through a darkened warehouse trying to escape the mob that now chases him; a reminder that if America chooses to remain willfully ignorant to its problems, they will inevitably be the country’s downfall.  “This is America” is Gambino’s first single since he dropped the 2016 studio album Awaken, My Love!. The song’s release coincided with Gambino’s appearance on Saturday Night Live, where he performed the new track, along with “Saturday,” another new track.  https://gph.is/2KEAKMc

description: “Redbone” is about paranoia and infidelity in a relationship. As a slang term, “redbone” distinguishes a lighter-skinned black person of mixed race. Bino fears that his efforts to keep this woman satisfied will drive her away.  In a Genius video, Ludwig Göransson, the song’s producer, recreated “Redbone” and explained that it was heavily inspired by Funkadelic, George Clinton’s 1970s psychedelic funk band. According to Göransson, Gambino even sent him Funkadelic’s music as a reference point for the production, which was created mostly on live instruments.  Gambino first revealed “Redbone” at his Pharos concert experience, but it officially premiered on BBC Radio 1 as Annie Mac’s Hottest Record. The track received worldwide recognition shortly thereafter, shooting to #12 on Billboard’s Hot 100 list. It got a second wind almost four months later when parodies of the song turned it into a meme.  “Redbone” was featured in the opening credits of Jordan Peele’s horror film, Get Out. In a February 2017 interview with Hip Hop DX, Jordan revealed why he picked the record for the movie:  Well, first of all, I love the “Stay woke”–that’s what this movie is about. I wanted to make sure that this movie satisfied the black horror movie audience’s need for characters to be smart and do things that intelligent and observant people would do.  The song won a Grammy for Best Traditional R&B Performance at the 2018 Grammys held on Jan. 28, 2018.

description: Because the Internet’s lead single houses some of Gambino’s existential thoughts with a catchy hook and beat.  He said of the song:  Everybody’s like, ‘It’s a love song,’ it’s kind of an existential thing. I’m just really scared of being alone. When I was little, there was a big dog down the street. I was really scared of it. But when I was with my sister, when I knew I had to protect her, I wasn’t afraid of the dog as much because somebody was there. I had a purpose…I kind of feel lost. I kind of lost that, I feel.  A video was released, featuring Gambino at an amusement park with a giant teddy bear. The track went Platinum in the US, and peaked at number 64 on the US Billboard charts.

description: https://twitter.com/DonaldGlover/status/404838406808551424  This song seems to fit a certain rich-boy theme, and does not seem to reflect Gambino himself, but rather a character or alter-ego, “The Boy.” This may have to do with the proposed supplemental screenplay that Gambino says will accompany the album’s release.      He said in an interview “Sweatpants” refers to the fact that rich people wear whatever the hell they want. Like you could show up to a black tie affair in sweatpants and mofos wouldn’t say shit to you if you were rich enough.  https://soundcloud.com/rosenbergradio/childish-gambino-takes-over

description: “Heartbeat” is a song about The One, and not being able to have or be with her. It expresses the complicated emotions that can occur when you’re sleeping with girls you don’t love and are still messing around with the ones you do.

description: The existence of the remix of the original “Girls Like You” was initially confirmed in a tweet by the band: https://twitter.com/maroon5/status/1001866378100359168  Leaving the original vocals & production intact, Cardi adds a Bronx-flavored verse to the pop record, rapping about having danced for dollars & being the life of the party among other things.  The remix also gained its own music video featuring several idolized women across an array of fields.  In September 2018, the song topped the Billboard Hot 100, becoming Cardi’s third #1 single, and Maroon5’s fourth. The song dethroned the uber-popular “In My Feelings”, by Drake, which led the pack for ten weeks.  On February 11, 2019, “Girls Like You” logged its 33rd week in the top 10 on the Billboard Hot 100, becoming the sixth single in the chart’s history to stay in the top 10 for that long. The song currently matches Ed Sheeran’s 33-week run of “Shape of You” in the top 10.

description: “What Lovers Do” is the first collaboration between Maroon 5 and SZA, and the second collaboration between Maroon 5 and the TDE label, following 2016’s “Don’t Wanna Know” with Kendrick Lamar. The track centers around a poker metaphor on the chorus.  Maroon 5 gave fans just a two-day notice that they would be releasing the song, along with a #WhatLoversDo social media campaign that enabled fans to hear a preview of the single before it was released.

description: “Memories” is a song by American pop-rock band Maroon 5, released as a single from their upcoming untitled seventh studio album. The song is an evolution of the more acoustic sound put forth in Maroon 5’s sixth studio album, Red Pill Blues, and specifically their #1 hit, “Girls Like You.”. Lyrically, the song is a reflective look back at the past, while also paying homage to those in our lives who may no longer be with us.  Structurally, the song is a reimagining of “Pachelbel’s Canon”, a famous late 17th/early 18th-century canon created by German Baroque composer Johann Pachelbel. The progression of “Memories” borrows from the harmonic sequence of “Pachabel’s Canon”, with additional changes made by the song’s diverse team of songwriters who include Billboard-charting hip-hop recording artist Jon Bellion and members of the production and songwriting team The Monsters & Strangerz.

description: Originally released as the ninth track on Maroon 5’s sixth studio album, Red Pill Blues, “Girls Like You” is an upbeat love song that takes a more acoustic approach than many of the other songs on the album. The song gained popularity quickly with the release of a remix featuring Cardi B.

description: “Don’t Wanna Know” is a song about past lovers. Adam focuses on not wanting to know what his ex-lover has been up to or who she’s been with since they broke up, while Kendrick shows his ex what she’s been missing.  This is Maroon 5’s first single since 2015’s “This Summer’s Gonna Hurt Like A Motherfucker” off of the re-release of their fifth album, V.

description: “Payphone” is a song by Maroon 5, featuring guest vocals from American rapper Wiz Khalifa. It was released as the lead single from their fourth studio album, Overexposed. The song marks their first collaboration together.  Lyrically, the song is a love story with no happy ending. Adam is really pessimistic about his empty life now that his relationship has ended.

description: “Best Friend” is the fifth song on Thugger’s first edition of Slime Season.  Produced by Young Shad and Ricky Racks, Thug comes hard with his crooning and braggadocios style to brag about his bestie.  This song was met with controversy upon release when Louisiana rapper Tokyo Vanity threatened to sue Thugger. According to Complex Magazine, Vanity is threatening to sue Thugger for copyright infringement, claiming he stole her song “That’s My Best Friend.”  The Fader interviewed the director of the music video, Be El Be, who shared his opinion on who Thuggers “best friend” really is:  If [Young Thug is] his own butler, if he’s catching himself with himself, making love to himself, if he’s in the bathroom getting changed and it’s just him and him—it’s showing his best friend is himself. That self-esteem! He’s a very stylish young man, so I would say that the inside meaning of that is that he is his own best friend.  On September 14th, 2015 the official music video was released by Young Thug. It is co-directed by Be El Be and the visuals show Thugger running into himself in everything he does. Pitchfork said it best (in regards to describing the video):  Young Thug’s video for “Best Friend” begins with Young Thug walking in on Young Thug, who’s in the process of hooking up with Young Thug. Then, Thug jumps in a car driven by Thug. Eventually, Thug’s head is served at a dinner attended by Thug.   Fun Fact: 5 months later from the release of the music video, Young Thug read out the lyrics on GQ  so people can understand him better and simply for laughs and giggles!  https://youtu.be/IVRXJ1Gd33g

description: On this track, Young Thug, J. Cole, and Travis Scott rap about what they would do with their significant others at “The London,” which could refer to a luxury hotel in either Beverly Hills or New York. They also boast their stature, wealth, sexual prowess, and ability to sell drugs. It is the lead single from Thug’s 2019 project, titled So Much Fun, and his first official release since his September 2018 EP, On the Rvn.  The single was first teased on May 11, 2019, when flyers were thrown out to attendees of Thug’s set at Miami’s Rolling Loud Festival. They featured the first line of Thug’s verse on the track and teased the song’s artwork and color scheme. https://twitter.com/1sabsad/status/1127412788354330624  The song was teased again on May 21, 2019, during a since-deleted live stream on Thug’s YouTube channel titled “Meet Me At The London,” which spanned over the course of more than twelve hours. The live stream focused on a woman painting a spider on a green canvas, again foreshadowing the song’s artwork. Travis' involvement was also teased by a woman filling a cactus-shaped piñata with candy.  “The London” received an official release two days later with less than an hour’s notice.

description: Thug teams up with hit maker London on da Track to create a booming new single about all the money he’s racking up. Check out the music video below!  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RAzzv6Ks9nc  Thug talks about how this song came about in his interview with Clique:  ‘Cause at any given time I could learn something and I really want to express it right when I learn it, like, 'Oh wow, pull the beat up.’ I got a check, like, I just got a check: 650,000. I’m in the studio, she bring me the check. I’m like, ‘What the fuck.’ I’m like, ‘Got a check I got a check,’ and just made a song.

description: This song is Young Thug’s first major hit that brought him much attention & made him a major face in the ATL trap scene.  The song’s major themes are addressed the name which is Young Thug’s admiration for / dependance on drugs especially, marijuana.  After a long time of waiting Young Thug finally delivered the official music video for “Stoner” on 10 May 2014. The video includes guest appearances of Birdman, Migos, Fabo and a lot more.

description: Danny Glover is most recognized for his role in the Lethal Weapon films. In these films, he was partnered with Mel Gibson.    Young Thug is saving these hoes (a la Danny Glover in the Lethal Weapon film series) because he’s so rich and it’s nothing to him. Thugger is also describing how he’s going to save them with some good wood.

description: “What Ifs” is a song recorded by American country music singer Kane Brown, featuring Lauren Alaina, taken from his self-titled debut album.  Lyrically, the song about the apprehension behind dating, looking on the negative possibilities, and then coming back and asking about the positives of a loving relationship, up to and including marriage.

description: “Good as You” is a song recorded by American country music singer Kane Brown. It is the second single to his second major-label album Experiment. Brown wrote the song with Brock Berryhill, Shy Carter, Taylor Phillips, and Will Weatherly. Dann Huff produced the song.  Brown wrote the song with Shy Carter, Taylor Phillips, and Will Weatherly. He said that the song’s idea came when Carter began performing on a ukulele, and then Phillips provided the lyric “Girl, I want to be good as you.” The song features banjo and electric guitar, and its lyrical theme is a love ballad to his wife, Katelynn.

description: “Look At Me Now” is a braggadocious track featuring rap veterans Busta Rhymes and Lil Wayne and is Chris' first rap-centered single to be released. The track was released as the second single from Chris' fourth album, F.A.M.E..  The mid-tempo record features a modern sounding beat produced by Afrojack and Diplo and an extremely impressive verse by Busta, both of which has been praised by most of the hip-hop community and the reviewers.  “Look At Me Now” performed well in the charts, peaking at #1 on Billboard’s Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs, Hot Rap Songs and Rhythmic Songs charts, at #6 on the Top 100 chart.

description: “No Guidance” is the long-anticipated collaborative single between superstars Chris and Drake. The R&B record finds both artists tapping into their melodic sides as they sing about a girl who’s “got it.”  The collaboration was initially teased by Chris on his Instagram stories and later previewed at a nightclub during Chris' 30th birthday party.  Despite having been at odds previously—due to an incident at a nightclub in June 2012—the two artists reconciled in 2018 via Instagram and later on stage when Drake brought Chris out at his L.A. tour stop.

description: “Privacy” is the 3rd single off of Chris Brown’s eight studio album, Heartbreak on a Full Moon, which was released March 24th, 2017 and produced by D.A. Doman. The song is an R-rated sex-drenched single about Chris and his girl, in the joys of sex and lust. It is also an interpolation of the 90’s reggae jam “Tight Up Skirt” by Red Rat.

description: “Love More” is a hard-hitting, playful track about sex. The track was released as the third single from X and was previewed during a performance at the 2013 BET Awards alongside Nicki Minaj, with the title later confirmed via Twitter.  “Love More” charted well in the United States, peaking at #23 on the Hot 100 chart. The track marks the third collaboration between Chris and Nicki, following April 2012’s “Take It to the Head.”

description: “Loyal” is an ode to unfaithful women that Chris can bag with ease. The track was released as the fourth single from X and is one of Chris' most popular tracks to date, peaking at #1 on the Rhythmic Songs chart and R&B/Hip-Hop Airplay chart.  Two versions of “Loyal” were initially released, both featuring Lil Wayne in addition to Too $hort on the West Coast version, and French Montana on the East Coast version. The third and final version featuring Tyga was selected as the single version.

description: In “Autumn Leaves,” Chris is clinging to the remnants of his relationship in an attempt to save it. He shows a vulnerable side in the melancholic track, pleading with his lover to stay. In a September 2013 interview with SKEE TV, Chris revealed that Lamar wrote his verse from the “mindset of a critic” who was coaching Chris through the song. in addition, Chris also praised Lamar’s lyricism and ability to paint a picture with his words.  “Autumn Leaves” was never released as a single, but a music video was shot for the track in Hawaii, with Chris' on-off girlfriend Karreuche Tran as the leading lady. This may allude to the fact that the track was written about their relationship.  “Autumn Leaves” marks the second collaboration between Chris and Kenny, following March 2013’s “R.I.P. (Remix)”.

description: This is Chris Brown’s East Coast version of “Loyal,” featuring French Montana instead of Tyga.  “Loyal” is a track about disloyal women—in this case, groupies—who just want to attach themselves to famous men in the music industry and have no intention of staying loyal—except to get a quick dose of fame.

description: “Sucker” is an upbeat pop song, and the band’s first single in almost six years. The brothers collectively portray someone who is infatuated with someone and for whom they would go to great lengths. The light rock instrumentation throughout the track is minimal, leaving the central focus on the brothers' vocals on their comeback single.  The song was teased in a YouTube video released by The Late Late Show with James Corden and was officially confirmed through a Twitter post:  https://twitter.com/jonasbrothers/status/1101133396200308736

description: “Cool” is the second single and second track on the Jonas Brothers' fifth album, Happiness Begins. It was released in 2019, after the Jonas Brothers took a six-year hiatus. The lyrics contain numerous references to the brothers' personal and professional achievements during their years apart. Reflecting on their individual success, they describe a shared sense of satisfaction and peace of mind.  In the brothers' track descriptions for Apple Music, Nick explained:  This song came towards the end of the writing process. We were trying to write a ballad, actually, but we ended up writing this instead because we all came to the studio feeling very cool that day. Feeling like a million bucks.  The music video for the track has a strong eighties aesthetic.  According to a press release from the band, it’s meant to evoke “1984 Miami” and  “channel the spirit of timeless eighties MTV, in all its decadent glory.” The video features multiple references to previous Jonas Brothers projects, most notably the video for their 2008 hit, “Burnin' Up.”  The track was first introduced to social media via Instagram:  https://www.instagram.com/p/BvwXuKrHJPr/?utm_source=ig_embed

description: “What a Man Gotta Do“ is an upbeat, Bollywood-inspired pop song by the Jonas Brothers. The track’s theme is mostly referring to someone’s true love and the lengths they would go to for them. It is the lead single from their sixth studio album.  The track was first announced on Twitter on January 13, 2020, and was followed by a teaser on YouTube the following day.  The official music video was released alongside the song. The video stars all three brothers alongside their respective wives. The video also features a cameo appearance from actor Matthew Modine.

description: “Hesitate” is a romantic track about wanting to help a lover through their burdens. It illustrates a new maturity that the boys possess when it comes to relationships and communication, contrasting their past, frustration-filled breakup songs like “S.O.S.”  According to Billboard, Nick said that this song is Joe’s “love letter” to his then-fiancée, now wife, Sophie Turner. The two got married after the 2019 Billboard Music Awards, and Joe explained to Harper’s Bazaar that they got legally married there, but are planning to have a more formal, “proper” wedding in the future.

description: The Jonas boys put a fresh spin on the Busted classic.  By covering what could be interpreted as a banal tune the Jonas brothers make an elaborate statement about the state of art. This shifts a fun jam from Busted, into a profound message about the lack of human imagination. By imagining the year 3000 and being thoroughly unable to describe any of the wonders there, the brothers are noting the inability of art provide what Jonathan Lear calls a ‘radical hope’ of a future that is entirely beyond modern cultural constructs.  Some lyrics were changed from the original song to suit JB’s young audience, including:   “And your great, great, great granddaughter is pretty fine” to “and your great, great, great granddaughter is doing fine” “Triple-breasted women swim around town totally naked” to “girls there with round hair like Star Wars float above the floor”    In addition, the line “it had outsold Michael Jackson” was changed to “it had outsold Kelly Clarkson” to accommodate the charts of the time — at the time of release, some of Kelly’s most recent hits were “Behind These Hazel Eyes” and “Since U Been Gone.”  All of these line changes both serve to make this song family-friendly and to emphasize how little is actually described about the future.

description: In this song, Maren Morris uses traditionally religious rhetoric to communicate the depth of her feelings about music and songwriting.  In an interview with Genius, Morris described it as “a road song.”  I wrote it in a place of inspiration. I get a lot of my songwriting done while driving around Nashville—sometimes it comes to me that way. I tried to write about that feeling, that connection.  https://twitter.com/MarenMorris/status/575786590582087680

description: “The Bones” is a song recorded by American singer Maren Morris for her second studio album, Girl. Morris co-wrote the song with Jimmy Robbins and Laura Veltz, and it was produced by Greg Kurstin. “The Bones” was released digitally as a promotional single on February 22, 2019 and was later serviced to hot adult contemporary radio on May 20, 2019 as the album’s second single.[2][3] The song became a sleeper hit, peaking at number 12 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart in 2020. A remix of the song with Irish singer Hozier was released on October 4, 2019.[4]

description: “Dear Hate” is Maren Morris’s ode to to the triumph of love over hate. While Morris has performed the song live for a few years, the studio version (recorded in 2016 with Vince Gill) was not released until October 2, 2017, a day after the tragic mass shooting in Las Vegas, Nevada. Maren posted the full track to YouTube as part of her response to the event, writing in a tweet, “Hate is everywhere, and I’m sick of not doing enough. In the darkest tunnel, there is still love & music. That’s what it’s here for. Here is Dear Hate.”  The song received an immediate, overwhelmingly positive response, leading to plans to release the track to iTunes and streaming services on Friday, October 6, with all proceeds going to the Music City Cares Fund—a charity specifically created to help the victims in Las Vegas. Continued positive response to “Dear Hate” led iTunes and streaming platforms to push the release date forward to October 3.  https://twitter.com/MarenMorris/status/914963639374839809

description: Maren Morris wrote “Once,” which she called one of her favorite songs from her debut album, after a random encounter with the mother of her ex-boyfriend just after a breakup.  It was just a random Wednesday morning, the week after we ended things … I saw his mom at the top of this, like, hill [at the Griffith Observatory in Los Angeles], and I thought she was a mirage or something. I went to write later that day, and I didn’t have any ideas, so I was like, “shit, I think I just need to write about what happened today and have sort of a moment, because it was just the craziest thing.”  Morris premiered “Once” in a live performance opening for Chris Stapleton at the Ryman in Nashville on February 18, 2016. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1V4zWZbRysw

description: On “1-800-273-8255,” Logic shows that suicide is never the answer to anyone’s problems. He wants people to know that there is always help available, such as the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline, whose phone number is the title of this song. In fact, the song was released in partnership with the NSPL.  In an interview with Genius, Logic said that this song details the story of someone calling the NSPL wanting to commit suicide but after a conversation with the NSPL representative,  the caller soon after decides he wants to live.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SOJTg9cL5bM  Logic teased the song various times on both Twitter and on Instagram stories as well.

description: “Homicide" is the third single released from Logic’s 2019 album, Confessions of a Dangerous Mind.  The track exhibits Logic and Eminem’s rapid-fire flows. The title seems to assert that they are lyrically murdering their detractors and non-lyrical rappers.  In a 2018 interview with HardKnockTV, Logic shared his thoughts on Eminem and his desire to collaborate with him:  It was awesome […] to be recognized by one of my favorite MCs of all time, one of my favorite artists […] I fuck with him. I want to work with him. I want to do a song with him. I think that could be pretty cool.

description: This song  samples “Carrot Man” by Sepalcure, and “Mad Crew” by KRS-ONE.  Thematically, the song explores the fear and desperation that pushes so many urban youth into gang culture.  Logic writes from his perspective as a child in the first verse, then takes the role of his older brother for the second verse.  Logic broke down this song in an interview with HardKnockTV.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TMGK1ZnetnE

description: On “44 More,” Logic raps just one verse made out of precisely 44 bars. He talks about issues ranging from family troubles to doubters in the industry, while boasting his current position in the rap game.  The song is a sequel to Logic’s song “44 Bars” from his 2016 mixtape, Bobby Tarantino, which also features exactly 44 bars. This was confirmed by Visionary Music Group on Twitter prior to the song’s release.  “44 More” marks Logic’s first solo release since his third album Everybody back in 2017.  The song was teased on Logic’s Instagram story on his 28th birthday.  https://youtu.be/mFIzLI_r1Tg?t=123

description: On “Everybody,”  Logic promotes racial equality, while interweaving his personal encounters with racism.  The song is Logic’s first release since his mixtape, Bobby Tarantino, which premiered eight months prior. He first teased the song on January 1, 2016 via Snapchat and Twitter and then during a Periscope in June.

description: Under Pressure’s title track was also its lead single, however, the single version was abbreviated to 3:50. Logic premiered the track during his While You Wait Tour, performing it during some of the shows.  Over a menacing beat composed of multiple samples, Logic cemented himself as one of the most notable young hip-hop talents with his steady wordplay and strong flow. The track was also self-produced, adding to how impressive this song is.  The official music video, which featured an alternate variation of the track, was premiered on October 9th. It was inspired by the Biting Elbows’s ‘'Bad Motherfucker’‘ music video—a fact Logic shared during an interview with DJ DUBL.

description: The identity of Nikki is finally revealed. In this song Logic struggles with his nicotine addiction which he refers to as Nikki; note the similarity of pronunciation – Nikki and nicotine. Logic understands that Nikki is not good for his health and is doing everything in his power to not go back with her, but lately Logic has been feeling like a slave for Nikki.    Logic goes by the nickname ‘Young Sinatra’ because his mom used to make him watch the legendary Frank Sinatra on TV when he was a child. Logic learned a lot from Mr. Sinatra and decided he wanted to bring that type of class to the hip-hop scene. However, Frank Sinatra was a known and common smoker. This could be one way that Logic was actually negatively influenced by his idol.

description: This is the remix of Harlow’s January 2020 hit single “WHATS POPPIN,” which, as of the release of the remix, reached #16 on the Billboard Hot 100.  Harlow first announced the remix a day before its release on Instagram, revealing the features included on the remix along with its cover art.

description: Being produced by the duo of jetsonmade & Pooh Beatz–the primary producers of one of Summer 2019’s hit songs, “Suge”–and being accompanied by a Lyrical Lemonade music video, this playfully grandeur single from Jack Harlow shows he has gained a new level of trust and recognition within the hip-hop community he had not yet seen in prior years.

description: Fresh off his 2020 XXL Freshman nomination, Jack Harlow pays homage to friend and NBA player Tyler Herro—with whom he is pictured on the single’s cover—on the eponymous single “Tyler Herro.” The song marks Harlow’s first solo release since his chart-topping remix of his breakout hit “WHATS POPPIN” and is the first single of his debut album Thats What They All Say.  “Tyler Herro” surfaced online ten days prior to its official release on October 22, 2020, alongside a music video starring friends Harlow and Herro.

description: Jack Harlow and Big Sean boast their success on “Way Out,” the second single from Harlow’s debut studio album That’s What They All Say.  Released alongside a music video two days before the album, the song is produced by Harlow’s friend jetsonmade, a third team-up that follows the duo’s January 2020 hit “WHATS POPPIN.”  Harlow announced the song just a day before its release with a short teaser posted on social media.

description: Sundown was released around the time that Jack moved to Atlanta. He describes listening to a lot of Clipse, and 2forwOyNE put a beat together, after Don Cannon gained permission from Pharrell Williams, sampling Hell Hath No Fury intro track We Got It for Cheap. Two versions of the song were made, with Harlow combining them into the version of Sundown that we have today. The track was the lead single off of Loose, and propelled Jack’s career.

description: Jack Harlow teams up with the suave Chris Brown to rap about close females on “Already Best Friends.”  The two detail encounters with more than one female at a time that are close to one another despite knowing each other for a long time or no time at all.  This marks the first collaboration between Harlow and Brown.

description: “Thru the Night” was the first single released from Jack Harlow in anticipation of his 2019 mixtape Confetti. The track features fellow Louisville native Bryson Tiller rapping alongside Harlow over a sample from Usher’s “U Don’t Have To Call.”  In an interview with Billboard, Harlow touched on what it was like getting Tiller to hop on the track:  I was in Las Vegas with [DJ] Drama, and Bryson’s assistant was there with us. Bryson and I have been cool on social media, but we’ve never had any direct contact. In the club I told her, “I got a record.” The next morning, she texted me, “Don’t forget to send me that song.” I sent it, and then he DM’d me saying it was hard. He didn’t do it right away, but I saw him at [the Kentucky] Derby and was like, “Yo, I’m ready for that verse. I got a project coming.” He knocked it out after we saw each other in person, and then we got to chop it up for real.

description: The lead single from Aldean’s 8th studio album, “You Make It Easy”, was written by Brian Kelly and Tyler Hubbard of Florida Georgia Line along with Morgan Wallen and Jordan Schmidt. As of this writing the song peaked at #2 on the US Country Charts.

description: “Dirt Road Anthem” is a country song written by American artists Colt Ford and Brantley Gilbert.  The duo also teamed up for Aldean’s hit “My Kinda Party,” and each recorded a version as well (Here’s Gilbert’s.)  Jason Aldean released the song as the third single for his 2010 album My Kinda Party. On November 30, 2010, the song received a Nomination in 54th Grammy Awards for Best Country Solo Performance. It is the best-selling song in digital history by a male country solo artist in the United States with over 4 million sold.

description: The first single off Jason Aldean’s sixth album. The song was was co-written by Rodney Clawson, Chris Tompkins, Tyler Hubbard and Brian Kelley – those last two dudes are from Florida Georgia Line.  Fire is a major motif in this song – the heat of passion. It’s a love song about the literal heat of desire.

description: “Girls Need Love” is Summer Walker’s breakout hit single. It serves as a confessional, candid vent on the plights facing girls who speak truthfully about the very normal need for affection, love, sex, or any other form.

description: Summer claims this is her favorite track! Sampling 702’s hit song from the 90s “Get it together” it’s foggy what Summer wants. She doesn’t really wanna stay, and she really doesn’t wanna go. Walker claims “I been all in my phone, I got options” ; which is super relatable. You ever been looking at a bunch of guys blowing up your phone with hella attention yet you’re stuck on a screen waiting for a guy to reply that left you on read for 3 hours? Yeah me too girl it’s okay! Summer speaks normality into wanting someone who does you wrong and running back no matter what. Sometimes the person you want can be so toxic for you but things like sex, previous feelings, and attachment keeps you in that unstable environment. Syncing the heart, mind, and body is what this track is all about. Sometimes you gotta leave the body and heart out of it and use your mind !

description: “Playing Games” is about romantic partners who are all talk and no action: Summer Walker confronts them for not putting effort into providing the bare minimum of attention, love, and physical/emotional availability.  In other words, the song calls out those who say they want you, but don’t show it.

description: “I’ll Kill You,” the 15th track off of Summer Walker’s debut studio album Over it, features singer Jhené Aiko, and is the first collaboration between the two artists. Throughout the song the two singers trade lyrics threatening to hurt any girl who comes near their guy.

description: “Session 32” is a raw and unedited piece that confronts an ex-boyfriend that failed to show his unconditional love for her and his commitment to the relationship. Even though it’s obvious that his perception of love is conditional and flawed, remnants of his presence still linger and she continues to think about him. He isn’t willing to go the extra mile to maintain the relationship and in that way, he doesn’t understand that being in love isn’t just all the positive things, but it also includes addressing the challenges and problems that arise.

description: On “Stretch You Out”, Summer Walker reflects on a relationship with a past lover. In the song, she laments about the shortcomings and demands of her ex lover who expected so much from her but is unwilling to return the effort. By the end of her verse, she determines that he’s not worth the stress.  She enlists A Boogie wit da Hoodie to deliver this message on a sultry track produced by London on da Track.

description: “Nobody but You” is a song recorded by American singer Blake Shelton for his compilation album Fully Loaded: God’s Country. The song features guest vocals from Gwen Stefani, marking the third collaboration between the two artists following “Go Ahead and Break My Heart” (2016) and “You Make It Feel Like Christmas” (2017).  Lyrically, the song describes a relationship between and couple and the love and admiration they share for each other.

description: “Turnin' Me On” is the only song in Texoma Shore co-written by Blake Shelton. It received an early digital release on November 1, 2017, two days before the album came out.  In an interview with Froggy 99.9, Shelton explained the songwriting process for the song and confirmed it is about his girlfriend, singer Gwen Stefani:  We were playing in Louisiana. I got to the gig, and I was sitting on the bus, and all of a sudden, I started playing this little lick on the guitar, and I came up with this chorus, “Turnin' Me On.” And I thought it was good enough, that it scared me. So I stopped working on the song, and I texted Jessi Alexander, and I said hey, I need your help, I think I got something here that’s pretty cool and I’m gonna screw it up. And she and Josh Osborne helped … basically, they wrote the song. I just had the chorus, but they wrote the song, and they even ended up making the chorus a little bit better. But, I just thought it was a cool song. I was literally thinking of my girlfriend when I wrote this thing. I don’t write that many very personal songs, but this one, I think, hits the mark.

description: This angry and sarcastic song finds Blake Shelton singing with venom about a bad relationship breakdown. Shelton didn’t write the tune; it was penned by Andy Albert, Marc Beeson and Wyatt Earp, but its lyrics about breaking up with a woman who’d wronged him got people talking in the wake of the singer’s divorce from Miranda Lambert. Many wondered if this was a grenade aimed at his ex.  Jake Owen was also offered the song, as he was going through a marital breakdown around the same time as Blake Shelton. “You’d be so surprised,” Owen told Taste of Country.  When I was going through my divorce everybody – every songwriter, everyone – was sending me songs that were like that. That new song Blake Shelton has out, ‘She’s Got a Way With Words’? That was pitched to me and I remember vividly the first time I heard that, I was like, ‘That’s a really good, cool song, very well written. But if I record this song and I’m taken literally – I don’t want my ex to perceive I did that to her.’  Andy Albert, Marc Beeson and Wyatt Earp put together most of the lyrics by just throwing jokes and phrases at each other, many of which ultimately ended up going into the song. “We’re just laughing over them for two or three hours, and then we started to arrange the different lines and put them together in a way that we thought made some sense,” Albert told Taste of Country.  Shortly after hearing the song, Shelton indicated that he wanted to cut it. He put the tune on hold in the early part of 2015, months before he and Lambert announced their divorce. “Then, unfortunately, he went through all of his personal stuff, the divorce and all of that, and I think the song sort of rang true to him in all that was going on in his life,” Albert said. “I feel like that’s one of the reasons why it made it all the way to the end [of the recording process].”

description: “I Lived It” was the third song from Texoma Shore to be released (after its lead single, “I’ll Name the Dogs,” and “At the House”), having an early digital release on October 31, 2017, three days before the album came out. Shelton performed the song live for the first time that same day, on NBC’s TODAY Show.  It became Texoma Shore’s second single on January 29, 2018 and a music video was released on March 2.  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=i_nLsG_asQg  The lyrics recount fond memories from the singer’s childhood that he believes must sound very peculiar (and perhaps even crazy) to anyone who didn’t share similar experiences growing up.  According to The Boot, Shelton says of the song:  That’s the song that really stands out to everybody as maybe the best song on the album. [It’s] one of the greatest songs I’ve ever had a chance to record. It’s hard to listen to this song without relating to it and having it take you back in time, and it’s hard not to fall in love with this song.

description: “Roxanne” is a 2019 single by Arizona Zervas. It started gaining traction on the popular app TikTok in October of 2019. “Roxanne” is the most popular song by Arizona Zervas to date.  “Roxanne” is a song that describes a girl called Roxanne, who, according to Arizona, likes to party and spend her dad’s money. It describes his relationship with her and just in general, how she acts and is.  Arizona Zervas said this about the song:  “Roxanne” is a song about a girl I wanted but didn’t need.

description: “There’s Nothing Holdin' Me Back” is about Shawn Mendes' ambiguous and manipulative relationship to a woman and his acceptance of the mental effects caused by her.  On April 17th, 2017, the Canadian singer-songwriter announced that he will be releasing this song as a new single on April 20, 2017.  This song keeps to the vibe of the Illuminate album, but it has a rougher and moodier feel to it.

description: On “In My Blood,” Shawn Mendes takes a heavier and more mature approach production-wise, while still sticking to his acoustic roots in the verses. The day before the release he tweeted a message to his fans saying:  This song is the closest song to my heart that I’ve ever written.  In an interview with Billboard, Mendes explained that the song is about his first experience with anxiety:  The concept of this song is about how it feels [when] you’re about to give up, and then you don’t. That’s the whole payoff in the chorus section…It’s not about when it happens. It’s kind of about something that I think everybody goes through and it’s something that I think people don’t talk about often, especially in music.

description: “Treat You Better” serves as the lead single for Shawn Mendes' second studio album. The single released on June 3, 2016. The song rocketed up the iTunes charts to number 3 within hours of release, in part, due to Shawn’s #BetteroniTunes drive, encouraging fans to buy it directly from the Apple service.  Lyrically, Mendes sings to his romantic interest, promising to be a better boyfriend than the one she currently has. There was some speculation that this song was about Camila Cabello, the Fifth Harmony member who was rumored to have been dating Mendes in 2016. Both of them, however, insist that they’re just friends.  In Seventeen, Mendes did talk about how he’s matured since his last album, referencing a past relationship:  I have songs about growing up, about ex-relationships—ex-relationship, I should say. I haven’t had relationships. A couple of songs about relationships with girls since fame.  This song’s instrumentation is heavy on guitar. Teddy Geiger and Scott Harris helped pen the lyrics (they were behind two of the major hits on Mendes' previous album Handwritten). Gieger contributed to production alongside Dan Romer, a veteran in the music industry who’s also worked with film, most notably scoring 2011’s Beasts of the Southern Wild.

description: On “Lost In Japan,” Shawn Mendes demonstrates his commitment to a lover by expressing his desire to visit them on the other side of the world. The song was released a day after the single “In My Blood.”  While “In My Blood” incorporates a rock-arena sound, “Lost In Japan” showcases R&B-heavy beats.  The song’s artwork is an ode to Japan, depicting the country’s national flower, the Cherry blossom.
